title: Anyone here move from the Note 8 to the S9 Plus and not sure about it?

thread.text:
I have Tmobile and used a Jump on Demand Jump to go to the S9Plus from my Note 8. I preordered it so I have both right now, taking a little time to decide which to actually keep. I really do like the S9Plus but not sure I want to let the Note go. 
Curious if anyone else has done the same.

replies.text: I left my note 8 yesterday as I upgraded to the s9plus and I'll tell you this. The 845 snap dragon chipset makes the s9 si much faster than the note 8 and also I believe oreo has helped it so much more then android nougat on the note 8. You wont be disappointed even the messaging app has been modified better.

I wasn't disappointed in it at all. But I still like my Note 8 that along with the idea of having the hundred and $28 back was enticing enough to go back to the Note 8 for now LOL. I tell you what though if the note 9 is like that S9 Plus that is something to definitely consider

Thanks Oscar. That does help. I've got Oreo and Samsung Experience running on my Note 8 already, so many of the updates to Samsung software are already on it. But the performance improvement sounds good. Wondering about the battery life...

thread.text: I did. My s9 plus is OTW but I have no regrets. I realise the pen. It has upgraded specs. I'm all good. And I got a additional 100 off from Best Buy. Now if I used the pen a lot I would have waited for the Note 9. But since I don't i will switch. But I'm the type of person that will most likely get the note 9 as well so there's that.

I switched too, also in TMobile, and so far I'm pretty happy. Surprisingly my 4g download speed has roughly doubled just from switching phones. 40~mb/sec to 100+. That's significant. 
One gripe though, I can't clear notification badges by long pressing an app anymore. That feature is gone. Very annoying as some apps, Facebook messenger being the biggest offender, tend to have badge counters that don't properly reset. This is infuriating, but the overall performance of this phone is so good in every other regard that I guess I'll just wait and see if Sammy brings it back. Fingers crossed.

I think you may be out of luck. I'm a JOD veteran and the only way you can return the s9 is by mailing it back. When you signed the EIP you agreed to return your existing phone to the store within 14 days. There's no way to terminate that EIP and reverse the upgrade. You have 2 option. 1 is to return your note 8 and then ask in store if they will allow you to jump right away from the s9 to the note 8 again or mail back the s9 which will be the only way they will terminate the EIP under the 14 day buyer's remorse. They cannot accept returns for online or phone orders in store.
I've just spoken with Tmobile about it - they advised I return it in store. I printed the paperwork and will stop at the store to do so.

TBH, it's nice and it's obviously better in many ways, but I'm keeping the Note8.
Yes, the S9+ is faster, but my Note8 isn't slow by any means (both are on Exynos SoCs). If anything, in daily operations, I never felt "Oh boy, I need the S9 because it's that much faster". Yeah, in heavy tasks, the S9 wins with zero doubt, but in normal operations, the Note8 is no slouch. And I'm one of those people who uses the S Pen every day, so the S9 is not going to appeal to me personally.
The camera on the S9+ is also great but I've been using HDR+ on my Note8 and aside from noise, I preferred its output overall. I would expect the same out of the S9.
It is a really good phone and I'm happy that many others seem to enjoy using it, but me personally, I'm sticking with the Note8 for quite a while. It's a great phone and doesn't seem to be a rebel against what I want it to do.

I just noticed something. It may have some bearing on this issue. I had a Ringke Wave case on my S9+ since yesterday. And I had a Luvitt glass screen protector. I'd also tested an i-Blason with a built in stiff but thin plastic screen protector as well as a Samsung LED wallet case with no screen protector.
One thing I had noticed when I first got my S9+ and used it without a case or screen protector for a couple of days was that interacting with the display was as smooth and fluid as interacting with my Pixel 2. Putting on the i-Blason case was the first time that fluidity got messed up. I had to press down hard to get touches to register. Finally I turned on the setting to increase touch sensitivity and messed around with the setting to reduce response to accidental touches of the edge display. Ultimately I turned that setting OFF. And I got back functionality but typing in that case was not fluid. 
Yesterday and today I was using the Ringke Wave case and a Luvitt screen protector. Even after installing GBoard and having the keyboard work normally again there still was a bit of a stutter and odd lack of fluidity in interacting with the display in general. I took off the case but left the screen protector ON. The fluidity is restored. 
I am now using a Ringke CLEAR case with the Luvitt screen protector and it's about the same as not using any case at all. I noticed this case has edges that do not curl over the edges of the phone the way the edges on the Ringke wave case did. 
TL/DR Summary: So I think when using rugged cases in combination with display protectors (or possibly even without a screen protector) be aware any user interface oddities you may notice might be due to your case edges not playing nice with the phone edges and/or the edges of the screen protector. 
Right now Amazon is full of bad reviews on screen protectors and my observations indicate it may not be the screen protectors at fault.

title: S9+ battery more expensive but only ~3300 mAh?

thread.text:
So the accuracy of the AccuBattery app and its "Battery health estimate" has been discussed several times in androidcentral forums and most people would not trust it, however, it's been fairly accurate for me, for example both my s8+ and note 8 were around 101% when new and after around 6 months they were at around 98%. When I have bought abused phones on eBay such as an old s7 or note 5 to use for trade-in and that the battery clearly last less than when new, accubattery says like 60-70%.
With my S9+ (T-Mobile, SD) that is only 5 days old, my estimated capacity is 95%, very close to 3300 mAh, some other users at XDA were complaining about the same.
However, other funny fact is that I was looking at the s9+ BOM compared to the s8+ and Note 8 and I found interesting is that battery is 37.5% more expensive on the S9+ ($5.5) compared to the s8+ or Note 8 ($4). When they announced the s8+ they said it would degrade only 5% vs 20% of other batteries after certain use but did they mention any difference with the s9+ why would it be 37.5% more expensive?http://www.techinsights.com/about-te...pple-iphone-x/
I noticed this too. My 9+ phone says it's health is already at only 95% and its max capacity is 3300 out of 3500.

replies.text: what model you got?
It's the Sprint SD model

thread.text: New S9+ the navigation bar disappeared after first night. I have done everything to include resetting the phone to defaults and it does not show up. Is this a glitch? Is it being fixed? ETA? I have no back button or recents button to close or switch between apps easily. It is not hidden as pulling up from bottom does not show it. It is simply gone. The home button works but not visible

You might go into settings and check to make sure it did not get switched off. I dont know why it would,but maybe? Also, try the hard press method. Just hold down where it should be in the middle for a second, see if it does anything?

Same issue... I can hard press home, but nothing else works. Don't turn that feature off unless you get one of the nav bar work around apps like "simple control". I also did a factory and "full" reset 2x before getting the nav bar app. Yes, I've turned the nav bar "show hide" option on/off several times and it has zero effect. I've tried changing the color and switching the button layout. This is the first thread I've heard someone else has this issue like me. Hope it gets fixed soon as I hate having to use the nav bar app for something so trivial that should work on a flagship device.

Mine did the same thing. I opened it and it was fine then about 3 hrs later my navigation buttons disappeared and I have tried everything! My navigation bar is there still but no buttons, home button works on hard press but that's it. I am super frustrated already. I hope they find a fix soon!

so did u all hit the little dot to the left side if the navigation bar to get it to stay up? u swipe up...then on the left side...there is a little dot. double tap that...it will stay up...double tap it...nav bar will slide down.

Yes, swipe up not working to bring back any nav buttons. Hard press only on home button works. Dot was there to dbl tap. Tried it the first time and it worked fine for "awhile". Next two "full resets" didn't mess with the dot and it still f'd up. 
Exactly as Caburns86 describes. Frustrating....

I have the same issuing with the disappearing navigation bar. The first time it happened, I did a factory reset and it came back. However, within a few hours it was gone again. This is super frustrating because I cannot utilize the recent apps function or the split screen view. I'm glad I'm not the only one this is happening to; hopefully that means they'll fix it soon. It's a beautiful phone otherwise!

title: "Regular" Slow Motion Video (240 fps) on S9+

thread.text: Kinda embarrassing, but I can't find where to shoot "regular" 240 fps slow motion video. I see the Super Slo Mo mode, but that's still a bit quirky for what I'm looking to do. Any help would be appreciated.

replies.text: Go to camera, then click the settings button towards the bottom left. Scroll down to edit camera modes then click on rear camera. Click the check box by Slow motion and it'll enable it. You can also reorder them if you like.

thread.text: Damn, thanks a lot... very much appreciated!
No problem! Glad I could help.

title: anyone get the unlocked model to use on Verizon?

thread.text: Trying to see what limitations there are to doing this. I've heard mixed things. I have a coupon at Best buy that can be used on the s9+ for unlocked no contract phones that will save me 10% off and wanted to use it on the unlocked s9+. Just wanted to see what I could be crippling myself with by doing this.. thanks

I'm using the unlocked on Verizon and the only thing I was really concerned about not having was visual voice mail but it turns out it has it so I'm perfectly happy. I've heard WiFi calling doesn't work and FM radio may not work but I don't use those features so I can't confirm. I'm glad I got the unlocked.

replies.text: Interesting that you got a working VZW VVM. I don't think that has ever happened with a non-verizon branded phone on Verizon network. I don't like the term "Unlocked" because the Verizon variant is not Carrier locked either. Can you possibly check WiFi calling settings?
How did you get visual voicemail?

Its a Samsung download and what I did was go leave a VM on my cell and when I went to get the VM off the phone, it immediately opened the Samsung download for VVM. If not, you should still be able to download from the Galaxy App store...
Does it transcribe to text?
As for old voicemails no. I haven't had a new one yet to test. But I did get the app running. I'll try and give myself a test voice mail tomorrow from wife's phone

thread.text: No wifi calling or hd voice and I have unlocked on VZ. VVM works and is actually a Samsung download, nothing to do with VZ. Only limitations I'm aware of and works like a champ. Just popped my VZ sim and sd card in and I was up and running in 5 minutes..

replies.text: Those are big limitations in my opinion. Everyone is different though. In the basement of a hospital, wifi calling is a must.

I wonder why no wifi calling. I do have the unlocked model and using on tmobile and wifi calling automatically turned on when I restored my backup. I would think wifi calling should work on any carrier. But maybe I'm wrong.
Yeah, you're wrong, unfortunately. Verizon doesn't play nice with unlocked phones as far as wifi calling. I believe I've read that AT&T was the same but I'm not 100%.

thread.text: Understood, have never used it myself. This is my first unlocked so I did the due diligence on what might be missing. Forums here had it pretty much covered prior to my pre-order..
Can you browse the web while on the phone ?

replies.text: I would think no if he can't get HD voice going. I'm not sure though since I don't have a S9 to test.

thread.text: That I could not tell you, but do not see a setting in the app...

I have the unlocked S9+ and I can make calls and browse the web on LTE network. When I put my sim in phone after booting up a voicemail app downloaded. It's not the same as Verizon's VVM, but i never used that anyway. I've had an unlocked S8+ on Verizon and you lose wifi calling and if you have asurion insurance they will not cover the unlocked phone.

replies.text:
Good to know. I have asurion right now from my pixel 2 xl and figured it stuck so it would be covered but I guess this answers that. 
I got my unlocked so plus at Best buy. Debating either going with their geek squad cost of 7.99 a month or Samsung premium care. Haven't decided.
That insurance part is good to know. Guess I'll make sure to grab the Verizon version of the Pixel 3 should I end up buying it.

thread.text: Did the same. Unlocked S9 and made calls and surfed at the same time with no problem.

title: Galaxy S9+ Black Crush and Gradient Banding Issues

thread.text:
My display had really bad color banding issues with lots of black crushing going on. The default wallpapers even looked bad. The upper corner, where the colors get dark, instead of being a smooth transition of colors, it would 3 or 4 blobs of distinct solid colors. And if you dragged the notification tray down, the blobs would move as the wallpaper darkened. When I watched Batman Returns, anything remotely dark grey would crush to pure black. So Penguin would have three black holes in the back of his head instead of looking like he had dark grey hair.
I could not reproduce any of this on my wife's Note 8 so I know this is not normal. I already successfully put in a request for a new one and hopefully the new one is as good as her Note 8 at reproducing color. Just curious if anyone else is having this issue.

replies.text:
I'm not sure if this is the same thing, but have noticed when I watch Netflix videos, darker portions of the video I'm watching almost completely blend into the screen. Doesn't make for a very good viewing experience. Basically, anything darker or shaded in the video becomes almost impossible to make out. 
I'm using the adaptive display setting on the FHD+ screen.

thread.text:
Yup, I just got mine and the banding is awful. Any dark colours are crushed and even gradients on normal colours are banding. I got my second today
for my partner and hers is exactly the same.

Same problem here. Any video with dark scenes is practically unwatchable. The black crush is much more apparent in a dim lit or dark environment where there are no reflections on the screen. Watching a movie during bedtime is impossible now.
I had a tough time explaining that to tech support (they barely understood the problem) but they arranged a swap for me next week.
It would be very interesting to know if the problem is widespread. Some people might not even notice it if they only watch video during daytime or in a well lit room with the brightness all the way up...

Maybe it's how they are calibrated. I'm not sure what to do with mine as watching content is pretty unbearable. I previously had a note 8 and s8 and none of them did this. 
Let us know if your replacement has the same issue. I will do the same if I get a replacement. 
Also, so you have light leak around the edge of the frame and screen? Because I have it on both units too.
I'll be looking in store tomorrow to see if units there are affected. having two units myself I think this could well be how they are. either that or the first batch.
Mine is completely the same but the banding disappears when I increase the brightness somewhere above 50%.

Issue is reduced significantly (but not completely) with Video Enhancer ON. But it's not ideal since I find the picture overly bright and saturated when using it.
Could this be a software issue? If so we might wait forever for Samsung to get it fixed...
Can anyone confirm if Video Enhancer helps them?
On a separate note, I don't have the light leak around the edges.

I don't think you'll be able to replicate the issue in stores because of the bright lighting. 
Glare can mask the issue and the displays could appear normal under those lighting conditions.
Worth a try though. Let us know.

I have the same issue. I compared the S9+ screen to my Pixel 2 XL and they look remarkably similar. The colors on my Pixel look very close to the S9. Turn down the brightness and they both have identical black crush. I have the video enhancer on.

I'd say it could be an Oreo problem, however, yesterday my wife received the Oreo OTA on her S8 and the screen is flawless.
Another weird behaviour is with the Display Tester app. For some odd reason, the app doesn't recognise the S9 screen as wide colour gamut capable. In the mean time, the screen ranks at the top of the smartphone world, including a review on Display Mate where they claim the screen has the largest coverage of Adobe standards. How is this possible?

Ok, trying to figure out the issue a bit further, I did a comparison between the S9+ (top) and the S8 (bottom) which I think clearly demonstrates the difference. 
Both phones are running Oreo 8.0 with the latest updates from Samsung (UK).
Settings are the same for both devices. Brightness is set to 50%, adaptive mode, QHD+ resolution, video enhancer off. 
It seems that the S9 is actually trying to resolve more detail from a dark scene than the S8 and that results in black crush and colour banding showing things that are not meant to be seen. Notice especially the wardrobe on the right side of the scene. The S8 covers the shadow details effectively and hides the furniture while the S9+ is trying to resolve them and makes everything visible.
Maybe the S9 is displaying a colour range which is not compatible with a standard video.
That's just my wild guess as I'm not an expert in image processing or video standards...
Also, I've been on a Samsung Experience stand today and all the devices I checked exhibited the same behaviour. It seems it's the new standard for now

The top image looks better to me
What movie is that?
Blade Runner 2049. And believe me you wouldn't like the picture at all if you'd actually saw the real thing. Especially in motion.

Top image also looks better to me, as well. When I saw them, I thought you were going to say that the bottom was the S9 and I was thinking, yeah that is pretty crappy looking in comparison to the top. I don't know, so far I enjoy my screen. No complaints.
Seeing the same issue on mine. Comparison between SP4, S7 and S9+:
I did the test in Display Tester app, and unfortunately here is the result:

replies.text: I see the same doing the test but as this is replicated in the screenshot I would say this is a software issue.

thread.text:
Are you sure the S9 is on top? I can clearly see the whole wardrobe on top, on the bottom phone its covered in black and can barely make it out. Plus the table on the left is much more clearer as well on the top phone.
I have the black crush issue on my S9+, and I think yours doesn't.

Try setting your screens out of adaptive display, since that uses software to try and detect what's on your screen and adjust accordingly. Try any of the others since it just sets the color to one of the other standards regardless of what's on the screen. IIRC, AMOLED photo is RGB and Basic is sRGB.

replies.text: Mine was set to adaptive (tried all of them and saw no improvement).

thread.text: The problem is there in every screen mode...

Andrei of Anandtech just replied saying it's a calibration issue that could be fixed with a custom kernel (not sure I want to lose any security features because samsung doesn't know how to calibrate their displays properly).

Here's an ultra low light comparison (ISO 6400 without a tripod hence the awful quality):
You can clearly see the S9+ struggling compared to the S7. :/

replies.text: Can you share what image/app is that to do the same test?

thread.text: I checked with my wife's Pixie (first model) and looks even worst.
Not pretty when compared to my old Nexus 5.

The top picture is the S9+. The photo I've taken can't capture the artefacting in those scenes during motion. For example, the black areas seem to be moving around like liquid.
I'll try another photo later. Unless like a member said, my problem is not black crush but something else completely.

replies.text: The black parts moving around like liquid is sadly just a common issue with oleds.

thread.text:
On mine I can't see anything below 5.
But I will have to try again tonight when it's dark

This sucks, it is the first time i get an Amoled screen with a perfect uniform white balance, and then this black crush thing happens, damn it.
I hate going through replacements as they might be worse, so its either i wait for a fix which is going to take a while, thats even considering its going to happen in the first place, or go for another phone, and at the moment there is no phone that seems worth it tbh.

Another try to demonstrate the problem.
Top image is S9+ bottom S8. Apart from the fact that the S8 image is much more natural with colour reproduction, notice the significant loss of detail on the hand and fingers in the S9+ display. The entire thing is covered with a greyish smudge.
I don't know if this is the black crush other members refer to but there is definitely a problem with my unit and how shadows are displayed in general.
Would you mind sharing the photo being compared. That would allow everyone to make a like for like comparison.

I don't mind sharing the photo attached, feel free to use it. 
However since it's a photo and not a screenshot, I'm not sure if it's going to be of any help. Unfortunately Google Play movies doesn't allow screenshots due to security policies.

Ok, I thought it was your own photo.
I see the issue in display tester but I have not noticed anything wrong while watching videos or photos.

OK. For users that want to try a direct like for like comparison with their devices, I attach a screenshot image and two photos showing how it's displayed between the two devices.
So, top image is the original screenshot, middle photo is S9+ screen and bottom is S8.
As for what to look for, pay close attention to the eggs in the photos and notice how they loose most colour detail on the S9+ screen compared to S8. I think it's pretty apparent.
Obviously if the image looks more like the bottom photo on your displays, you don't have the issue.

There is clearly something wrong with yours.
While the screenshot seems darker I can see it well in my s9+.

Photos normally make the image appear brighter than what actually is.
The test is done by cranking up a bit the brightness of your display and focus on the egg details. If they don't appear smudged, your display doesn't have this particular issue.

That's totally my issue. It's as if there isn't enough colour depth or something. There's gradient banding everywhere and crush all over the place. White balance is excellent for the first time, but everything else is just off.

replies.text:
Exactly. White balance is the only good thing with my display. Sadly, it feels like a massive step backwards in every other aspect. Colour saturation with adaptive mode is duller, I can see some minor light leak over the edges and the display exhibits ghosting when switching fast from a bright to a dark scene or vice versa.
I'll get my replacement tomorrow. If it's the same story, I'll be sticking with my trusty S8.

thread.text:

thread.text: I got my replacement... new s9+, still have the problem but much less noticeable compared to my prev s9+. Samsung IL says it's a software bug and should be fixed via OTA

Hi guys,
I realize nobody uses phones anymore to actually talk to other people (), but I do. Need it for business, etc. I've found that the call quality is absolutely horrible, whether I use the speakerphone or just use it normally.
Everybody said it is super quiet, they can barely hear me, and it is muffled almost like I'm underwater. I listened to other people use my phone, and sure enough, that's exactly what it sounds like.
I tried it with a case and without, with screen protector and without, in Safe Mode and without, HD Voice and without, and it sounds exactly the same. Receives the person I'm talking to just fine...actually quite loud and clear.
Is there any setting or such that can be fooled with to make things better or any tests that can be done? I'm coming from a Motorola, where the call quality was absolutely amazing. To be honest, things are almost unusable in this state, as I'm constantly having to repeat myself, especially when there is background noise mixed in, like while driving.
Thanks!! This is driving me nuts!

maybe it's related to how you hold the phone. honestly, im not sure what is wrong, but the same thing happened to me and my gf a few times, and the quality became "normal" again after she adjusted her grip.
Try using a Bluetooth device? Reflash your firmware? If those didn't help then you probably need a new device. Mine sounds semi bad on speakerphone as well.
When I had mine, the call quality was good - and in fact, the speakerphone quality was much better than the Note 8.

Don't discount the suggestion by Caspavio. I had the same problem when I first started using my Note 8. Turns out I was using my pinky on the bottom to help support the phone and obstructing the mic. Just changed my grip.
Call quality is fine with mine. If it's not how you're holding it, then you probably need a replacement phone.
Transferred all apps from old S8 to new S9 via the cable and I'm getting a lot of phantom notification sounds. Guessing it may be an app. Not sure how to find the issue.

Are they possibly unread text reminders? I noticed that was happening on mine. I would get a ding every minute till it was read. 
Just a thought......
I use textra. I did go into the default messaging app and there was an unread message in there so I cleared that. I'm hoping that fixes the issue. Thanks.

That didn't seem to fix anything. I was still getting notifications and decided to do a full wipe and start over. The only data I restored this time was my pictures and video files. No settings, no apps, etc. I am still getting these phantom notifications occasionally but it isn't constant. This is an ATT S9.

I copied everything from my S7 to my S9 via smart switch and the cable, and I don't have this issue. What did you use for the transfer? I didn't use the AT&T setup & transfer app that came pre-installed, I went into settings and straight to smart switch. It copied my call logs, texts, apps, data, everything.

I used the cable and smart switch both times. The last time I only did photos and media. I had to redo all my settings. Over the past 2 days, it seems to have quieted down. I don't think it will be an issue any more, time will tell.

Have you solved this? Mine was doing this as well I *may* have solved it. Hasn’t happened in a while anyway. I think it was notifying whenever the weather updated. As soon as I turned weather notifications off in settings it hasn’t happened in 5 or so hours.
Could it be NFC? Does it go away if you turn off NFC?

It isn't NFC as that is the first thing I turn off. I use a weather app and widget so I don't know if it could be the built in weather app or not. Also mine seems to have settled down where it isn't doing it anymore. There was also a firmware update I did last night from ATT. Not sure what that resolved. Battery life doesn't seem as good as my S8 for some reason.

Just experienced this myself. Received 3 notifications this morning. One email, one eBay and one Facebook. Before I had gotten around to checking them they already disappeared on their own and the respective app had no new notifications waiting for me. Meaning there actually wasn't anything new.
The last notification (Facebook) that appeared came and went within seconds.

I wasn't getting those types as you know what they are. The default notification in setting was going off on my phone and I had no idea what was causing it. Normally facebook has a different sound. Whatever was going off was using the sound in the default notification as I was changing my sounds per app such as email, text, facebook etc.

I'm a habitual phone changer. Most recently have had a pixel 2 XL and a long time iPhone user (including the 8 plus and X). 
The s9+ is blazing fast. I love the screen and I really am happy with the front facing speakers. I love taking selfies so that jury is still out. 
My most welcome change is the upgrade in sound quality when using headphones. One of my biggest gripes is the pixel and older Galaxy models didn't get as loud as iphones with headphones but this seems to have changed with the s9! Hoping I keep this one for awhile

replies.text: I 2nd that I've been using my 9+ fully and putting it threw numerous paces and thus far its handled everything lagless I do feel like this years improvements are making a difference in my usage coming from an 8+. The ultimate test is over time I'll see how it ages.

I have had the same exact phones. I have not pulled trigger on s9 yet though. How do you rate it vs all of those?

Hard actually their all so different. I preferred the 8 plus to the X actually. I didn't like the notch at all. Made watching videos hard for me. And battery life was better on the 8 plus. I'd rate the Note 8 above both of those for me anyway but battery life was worse than the iPhone 8 plus. So far it's like the S9 plus for me is a combination of all those. Battery life is stellar. Yeah. I have the AT&T model.

Also exactly same experience! Note 8 was barely 4 hours SOT and S9+ is 6 hours SOT (both using them the same way everything on, auto brightness, streaming video or sound via BT a lot). I expect the s9+ battery to get worse over a few months but hopefully not too much.
Weird thing is that AccuBattery app says my estimated capacity is 95% and close to 3300 mAh.
Completely agree with the whole post, the speakers sound better than expected and the whole better quality from bluetooth headphones/speakers was also unexpected but VERY VERY welcome

They need to add this field back in. I tried using Google Contacts and Google Messaging. If you have an open text conversation open is Google Messages it will allow you to add a custom notification tone. However, once you delete that conversation, which I do typically to clean up texts, it defaults back to the standard notification tone again. If you use third party contacts or messaging, they don't sync on the Gear Watch app. Also, if you disable the stock contact app (package disabler pro) it then deletes the stock phone app and the contacts in that app. You can't win. I just wish they would go back to the s8 version of the contact app and then there would be the custom notification field back in. Hope there is a fix.

title: New phone battery strategy; top up, or fully drain?

thread.text:
What's the current thinking on this? I was regularly putting the old S7edge on the wireless charger to top it up, but wondering if that was doing more harm than good. 
What's your strategy?
Keeping it topped up is WAY better for it than fully draining it. Frequent shallow discharges and shallow charges are healthier for it than deep discharges and deep charges.
I always try and do 2 cycles 100 down to 2% and then use it regularly

replies.text: Is that just out of habit from phones years ago or do you think that's necessary/helpful?
Both lol

thread.text: Thanks!

title: Samsung direct unlocked s9+ have band 71?

thread.text: Just curious as it makes a difference for me !! Thanks.

Yes. It should. However I do not know if the band 71 is Firmware dependent. I am trying to see a way to view the LTE bands on mine to help out. The main thing to know is the Factory unlocked model has the same FCC ID as the carrier variants (A3LSMG965U). The FCC ID should be tied to the type of Hardware or radios and so like the S8/S8+ they have one type for multiple models carrying the Snapdragon processor.
FCC ID: A3LSMG965U
Label: SM-G965U
Label: SM-G965U1
Label: SM-G965W
Label: SM-G965XU
It falls under a different label under the same FCC ID. The software onboard and bloatware is less. However if you want T-Mobile VVM or the T-Mobile software preinstalled it won't come on the SMG965U1 factory unlocked model.
Edit: confirmed from my sm-g965u1
Yeah as far as I know all the US models have same hardware including the same bands. It's just they run different firmware based on the carrier or unlocked.

Hey everybody! I got my S9+ on Tuesday and so far so good. I was coming from an iPhone X and Pixel 2 XL (both used a little bit for the past four months) and am coming out pretty impressed so far with how the phone handles and the new features and improvements. Lets get into it!
Likes
Hardware: First let me give a big thank you to Samsung for listening to fans and moving that FP sensor! Aside from that, and the camera on the S9+ being 2 and vertical, it's the same great design of the S8+. The bezel is smaller I guess but I don't notice much, it is much smaller than the Pixel 2 XL and the screen is also about a million times better. I didn't have screen issues with my Pixel, but the quality wasn't great during darker scenes on a movie or video and I got a weird scrolling issue that I had on the two devices that make everything stretch out as I was scrolling and none of that is even remotely present on this display. The speakers are LOUD and sound pretty durned good for my tastes.
Software: I must say this UI is largely the same but with the added benefits of Oreo coming out of the box (instead of an update like with the S8 and Note 8) and it runs smoothly on the SD845. The add ons like Bixby and S Pay work well with S Pay being a star for me. I love getting rewards for using it and it works in a surprising amount of places that Apple Pay and Google Pay don't work. I haven't seen ANY lag at all which is awesome because I noticed a teeny bit on my Note and S8 even straight out of the box. Well done Sam.
Camera: This is supposed to be the key improvement this year right? Live Focus works well, not quite up to par with whatever the heck Google did with their software but the bokeh looks good most of the time, it's faster than Apple's Portrait Mode by a fairly wide margin and it also allows for editing of the bokeh and the blurriness of the background which is cool to me. The video on this phone looks great, especially in 4K when viewed on a 4K display (like my Samsung 55" 8800 series in my living room, yes I'm bragging on my display) and is stabilized well and has good sound. The front camera is even pretty decent, though I don't do selfies, I don't like looking at myself a whole lot. The super slow-mo is...cool? Idk I haven't been able to get a good video of something that I want to see going that slow yet. I do love the UI better than the Pixel Camera. I feel like Apple had it right with the whole swipe to get to different modes and Samsung copied them and it works for me, others may disagree though and thats cool too!
Battery: This one is harder. So day one was setup, obviously the battery went to crap quick with downloading apps, setting up accounts, etc. Day two was a mixed bag but I was also trying to use that horrible Smart Switch to try and drag some stuff off of my iPhone and Pixel, more on that in a minute. Since then though my battery went 12 hours and had 3.5 SOT and my battery was at 38% when I went to bed last night. It is sitting on 82% right now after almost 3.5 hours and about 1.5 SOT so I'm fine with it. It also charges quick, duh, and that makes it draining not a bit deal at all to me. For reference I watch a lot of YouTube and Twitch, stream music and audio ALL DAY at work, like 8 hours+ with the IconX 2018 and I also tend to text, talk on the phone and more quite a lot throughout the day. I don't hold the phone back from anything so everything is syncing in the default manner and I have a lot of location services turned on as well. Basically, I use it, it never dies during the day and I top off at night like most people.
Intangibles/Misc: I love all of the stuff Samsung still crams into their stuff. Headphone jack, wireless charging, expandable storage, FP scanner, facial detection, iris scanning, Always On Display, variable Aperture, stereo speakers, HDR display, etc. etc. etc. phew! That's a lot of stuff and it all works great and makes it for probably the most well rounded phone available every year.
Dislikes:
None
.
.
.
Okay just kidding there are a couple.
Bluetooth: Randomly cuts out for a second and scares me to death when it does because it makes a loud sound in one, or both, ear buds. Kind of a bummer but every phone I have had recently does something weird with BT so not too awful.
FP scanner is still a little bit close to the camera. I've rubbed the camera a few times in the 2+ days and I feel like maybe the camera being in the corner of the back instead of right next to the scanner would help. Still way better than last year though.
Bixby button: Nuf said
This last one is more of a complaint in general about earbuds and my ears too but nobody makes comfy earbuds for my ear shape. AirPods legitimately made me bleed, Pixel Buds were super uncomfortable, and the IconX are the best fit for me so far but also kind of hurt when I remove them. Luckily, unlike the previous 2, that pain goes away quickly, but it is still weird to me. Not really anyone's fault, just wanted to place it here.
So all in all a great showing by Samsung for the S9. I'd like to say I'll hold onto it for awhile but I know myself. I do think that it is incredibly solid and a worthy successor to the S8 and Note 8 as it ticks all the boxes and then some and offers improvements over the previous year. For those wondering, if you have an S8+ and it is still running well, keep it. The S9 is awesome but I wouldn't say it's enough to upgrade from last year's phone.
Hope you guys likes my initial impressions! Sound off below with your impressions, I'd love to read them.
Great review. Thanks so much for the detail! So if you had Note8....worthy move?

replies.text: Not really, the Note has dual cameras, 6gb of RAM and a very good processor in the SD835. I think once is get official Oreo it'll be basically the same phone save for the FP scanner location, orientation of the camera, and speakers. If you have the Note, keep it unless you can get a great deal and essentially trade.

thread.text:
I posted this over on the WC forums but adding here to. Thanks @Jtshurtleff for letting us all share.
S9+ -- mini overview from my own use:
The S9+ SD 845 model G965U1 Coral Blue, no case yet. Disabled most google apps/services except play store and photos. Using bk disabler disabled many of samsung bloat software and certain features I do not use, like the Edge panel, Samsung pay, etc.
Battery life is excellent. I have a minimalist AOD always on and SOT is at about 5hrs, 2 Exchange accounts, 3 tapatalk accounts, mms/sms/handful of phone calls, web surfing, youtube usage a bit, and about 10 Groove tracks played more or less. Now with total time off the charger of 19hrs or so and I have 34% left.
The display is as we would expect. Samsung uses a proprietary driver I believe along with their display service(s) and panel, and the brightness and color modes compliment each other well. The Sunlight readability is pretty good. But I have not assesed all the panel configurations to see which is optimal for my use/needs. It has done some buggy things though, like prior to the latest OTA update night mode was funky and super orange. It would kick in a couple seconds after unlocking the phone each time I unlocked it while enabled, meaning it was turned off at unlock and turned on after the screen got settled. Another is that more than twice I have unlocked the phone during the day and Autobrightness crapped out and the display was completely dim and would not adjust to a readable brightness.
The Sound from this thing is top notch. The stereo speaker setup and dolby atmost are just great. I thought the Idol 4s was nice and the most acurate with sound reproduction (without and EQ mind you) but the way Samsung did theirs and combined Harmon speakers just works excellently. And you can crank it loud with little distortion. Off the 3.5mm wire I am still trying to get what I think sounds good to my ear but so far the quality and range are excellent.
Call quality is great and it has used Wifi calling mostly. It is fast and snappy. The UI works for me. I download a dark them called sd-Black by aire design and it reminds me alot of the Windows Phone UI now. The finger print sensor is fast and accurate. Samsung has a ton of goodies baked into the OS that I am not sure I have looked at even half of them thorougly. I kninda like the one handed mode double tapping the home button 3 times, but it is not ideal imo. I can provide more detail on that if anyone needs...
The camera is pretty good. I have not fully used it enough to know how to use it quicky and fluidly. I need a case to be able to hold it appropriately and safely when trying to snap photos. However the few that I have taken are good. In low light it is a good shooter too. I have not really used the camera though to make a complete judgement from y view but it works really well and for my average camera usage it is good. I like that it uses a motion photo feature like living images for photos you take. 
The phone is a bit thicker, heavier wider and a bit shorter than the S8+. It feels easy to use and should be even better once I get a case. I ordered a spigen liquid air armor case.
The one thing that is really impressive on it so far is the battery life. I did disable a lot of stuff. But compared to the s8+ with the same battery size this is good. It should be expected from the SD 845 anyway right?. IMO the standby drain is where I think it excels the most and why the stamina is so good when it needs to be in use.
It really is a great device to use for me personally if moving from a Lumia. I just hope Microsoft has an Andromeda-like device lined up soon that can replace this hunk of glass though (sorry just had to say it). Am hoping what they want to do with their new device will be something I and others can use and need for our daily lives to replace devices like this most were forced to move to. I moved off Google entirely except gmail and was happy for several years. Now I have to embrace it a bit more unfortunately. I have not decided what I will do with all my Lumias yet. I will try to provide more about my use with this device as it progresses.
Appreciate the reviews
To the extent that Bixby ever works...

replies.text: Bixby works great for me. It's very useful. Love having both. Bixby and Google Assistant. Both have their own functions and work well together.

thread.text:
So a quick check in after having a weekend with the phone. For reference I was off work Friday, hung out with my son, took my daughter to school, did some cleaning, played outside a bit, did boring stuff until my daughter's Tee Ball game and also went out to dinner. I didn't use my phone a ton that day, took some pics, tried downloading the Pixel Camera, watched a little YouTube and made a few calls and texted a bit. Also played a friend in Magic via Hangouts which TORE UP my battery, like 80% in about an hour, and then recharged in about an hour. Saturday was a rainy lazy day for the first half and then we went outside and went on a walk, took some pictures and videos of my kids and pups, did some more YT watching, tried setting up Kodi and that was mostly it. Sunday was a ton of pictures, outside time, Tee Ball pictures, using Samsung Pay at stores, being out and about.
So my biggest gripe so far is the camera. To me, it is nowhere close to the Pixel 2, doesn't do as well as the iPhone in normal shots, and the low light camera lacks any detail. I have a few pics to post and will do so below but I just feel like Sammy took a huge step back here, almost breaking the phone for me. If I can figure out how to get Pixel's camera on here I will and I will keep it but for now it's leaning towards a no because of how much I use the camera. The software has been brilliant though, easily blowing through any process, no bugs yet, hiccups rarely and is genuinely pleasant to use. The battery is hit or miss. Friday, not using it much, I ended the day at about 40% and Saturday, with heavier but not heavy use was at 22%. Yesterday I was at 35% when it went on the charge after using it for pictures a S Pay a bunch. I like the FP sensor a bit more than the S8, enjoy the new speakers and LOVE the screen. But the camera...what am I doing wrong?

See pictures for reference. 
Sent from my SM-G965U using Tapatalk

I don't know after posting these. They look better than I thought, maybe I am just looking for a reason to not like the camera. The low light still has sharpness issues and the window in the shot of my daughter is blown out but that was with the f/1.5 so that could be why. Still hoping for the Pixel camera port as the Live Focus mode has yet to yield a great pic.

replies.text: Yeah, I was looking at them and honestly they look pretty good. I dunno, I've got both the Pixel 2 XL and this and both are great cameras. I think they beat each other about equally. It really just depends on the situation. I actually prefer the S9+ for low light. Everyone is different though. I plan to keep both phones.

Yeah I am starting to agree. I hated the Pixel XL camera last year until I used it a bit so maybe Samsung's is growing on me. I feel like the picture I take turns out different that what I am seeing initially and it is throwing me off. I also might be going blind, no clue.

title: Did anyone else return their S9 to keep the S8?

thread.text:
I got my S9+ and thought it would defy all of the negative articles saying it was exactly the same as the S8. It didn't. I went through the settings, the camera, the intelligent scan, etc. Yes, the speakers, camera, Dolby Atmos, and Intelligent Scan were all great but nothing to lose my upgrade over. The fingerprint sensor works faster but for those who hated the placement of it on the S8, it's still right by the camera and easy to accidentally miss and smudge the camera lens. The phone screen dimensions are actually a hair smaller according to the specs. 
Also, Samsung is doing away with the upgrade annually program with Verizon so if you use your upgrade from S8 to S9, you lose your chance to upgrade to the next Samsung phone that actually has major changes unless you pay off your S9 completely first. That's a helluva lot of money to fork over for a phone that's almost exactly like the last one you had. 
The S9, to me, is akin to Apple's upgrades from a 6 to a 6S, etc. They should have called the S9 the S8s.
I'm keeping my S8+ until I see a major update to form, function, and aesthetics.
You?

title: How many bt headphones can I connect to one S9/S9+? And How?

thread.text:
Hello people!
You know my query
Header tells everything!

How many headphones you have? I have many Bluetooth devices connected to my phone and honestly I don't know if there is a limit. How to connect? You put the Bluetooth device in pairing mode (refer to that device manual) and go to Bluetooth settings on the phone to pair it up. 
Once you pair the phone automatically connects to the last connected Bluetooth device from then on. You can also manually connect to thm from the Bluetooth settings.

But, if you mean, how many headphones can you connect and listen through *simultaneously*, then the answer is exactly one.
Only option for simultaneous output would be to add a Bluetooth splitter. But even those will usually handle a maximum of two output devices.
go to settings>connections>bluetooth, hit the 3 dots in the upper right corner and select dual audio. you can pair 2 audio devices at once.

So, I can connect 2 headphones at once. That means if I'm watching a movie, I can share the audio with just one friend.
What's that Bluetooth splitting thing BTW?

replies.text: correct. bluetooth splitters are basically a device that receives your services bluetooth signal, then splits the signal via headphone jacks.

thread.text: Thanks for helping

The S9 has a feature called Dual Audio, which allows 2 BT audio devices to be paired at the same time with audio playing through both.
Go to Settings, Connections, Bluetooth, switch it on if it isn't already, tap the 3 dots on the top right and select the option.
Just want to know, is this dual audio feature is specific to this particular smartphone? Or any smartphone with bt 5 or above have this same feature in common?

replies.text: As far as I know, it's on the S8, Note8 and S9.

I've owned most every Nexus and Pixel phone, including my current device Pixel 2 XL. None of them have offered dual audio output.
It appears to be a Samsung thing.
Once I read somewhere that in some latest Motorola phones one can connect upto 5 bt headphones. I can be wrong though
That's not simultaneously though. You'll only hear audio out of one of the devices at once.

thread.text: AT&T here I can go two days, maybe do a clean reset from new and make sure you're not double syncing, there. is a lot of useless syncing on this phone. Disable the Samsung cloud and Google cloud and go into Google and all your social media apps and see what's on for permissions (like location). I'm using Facebook lite and messenger lite and, disabled all the bs permissions they ask for in settings and that changed the phone for me quite a bit. You really have to tweak things on this phone from stock to get it just right. Disable the games and AT&T bloatware in settings is another tip I could give you. You could also download package disabler and completely turn off apps you don't want running. In battery settings you could also go add sleeping apps that you don't want notifications on and turn them off so they only work when you open them. I don't like a lot of notifications so I turn a lot of apps off and the phone is nice and quiet and I get what's important.

replies.text: Review in general state the S9+ has similar battery life as the S8+, but the S9 is almost an hour less overall than the S8. Even some reviewers admit it seems odd.

thread.text: Check your mobile signal strength. Aside from the screen, the largest battery consumer is the radio transmitter when the signal from the tower is weak. (If the signal from the tower is weak, the phone transmits at full power to get a better signal to the tower.) A strong signal (around 90dbm) will result in a longer battery life. (Which can mean that you need a different carrier.)
The point is, I'm using my S9 exactly how I used my Pixel 2. Same locations etc. The battery performance is just not great especially since the S9 battery is larger than the Pixel 2's.
It's a new device. Let the battery get a few cycles and get conditioned.

title: S9+ poor phone reception - worse than S7

thread.text:
I've had my S9+ a few days now and the phone reception is noticeably worse than my previous S7. 
I took my SIM from my S7 and put it into the S9+ 
Immediately the very first call I took the call dropped after a few minutes. This has continued ever since. 
I have weak phone reception where I am but my S7 managed ok 90% of the time on 2 bars. The S9 shows less than this. The only way I can have any phone call of more than a couple of minutes is to change to 3G and even then it sometimes drops. 
For a new phone this is very disappointing. 
Has anyone else experienced this? 
Any suggestions?
I'm considering sending it back as faulty. 
Thanks

replies.text: What service do you use? Do you have an S9+ that's specific to the network, or an unlocked model?
Call your carrier and give them new IME number so they can refresh the account. Most of the time, replacing SIM does matter.
Try hitting carrier configuration twice and u can update carrier settings

thread.text:
Its an unlocked phone from Samsung using the same SIM that was in my S7 on Vodafone.

title: Badge notification on stock email app

thread.text:
My new Galaxy S9 arrived yesterday on pre order and for the most part I'm pretty happy. When I receive emails or don't open them the little count badge doesn't seem to appear, I've checked all my notification settings and everything is switched on I even tried turning them off and on again and the problem still hasn't gone. Anybody any idea what the problem could be?
Thanks in advance.
Same thing here. I get no notifications of emails and they aren't pushed to my phone even though the settings are all correct.
Same issue with the app badges.

If the S8 Oreo update is any indication Samsung is adopting the notification badges used by Google, which are tied to the information in the notification shade. If the app is not reporting notifications in the shade, there's no dot on the app.
I seem to recall having to enable a permission on my Pixel in order to get this working, even though everything else was enabled.

In my case, I believe it was enabling notification access on the Pixel Launcher, or enabling the notification dots in the app notifications for the launcher.

thread.text: I had one on my Note 8, that did the portrait mode perfectly. Found it on XDA, for Snapdragon versions of the Note 8. I restored it to the S9+, but it crashed the phone.
Why, whats wrong with the camera?
I do agree Pixel 2 is still a shade better than S9+ inspite of DXO ratings
Thread locked for the time being due to a forthcoming cleanup.

Thread re-opened.
Let's keep it civil and clean this time, yeah? And let's not go way off-topic to what the OP was asking for.
Yes, it works on the S9. Put it on my friend's S9+ and neither one of us can tell a major difference in photos.

Here's my personal take.
The app should work on the Snapdragon S9 since it uses the same DSP family as the other recent Snapdragon-powered devices. For the Exynos, it's a bit flaky. It works on my Note8 but ZSL doesn't work, meaning that I have to use the "HDR+ On" mode, meaning longer capture and processing times.
As for the differences in output, you'll mostly see it in color and dynamic range. The HDR+ app will tend to pull out much more detail in shadows and highlights due to its method of processing (instead of bracketing, it takes multiple lower-exposure shots to reduce noise, averages them out and brightens the shadows to compensate) and also tends to bring out colors which can be a bit closer to what we may perceive.
However, Samsung's app works natively with the S9, so you'll get all the benefits and it also has lower noise levels due to MFP. And it's the only way you will get the 960FPS slow-mo feature and the ability to adjust the aperture.
Honestly, a lot of us can argue over which is better, but the bottom line is that regardless of which app you use, you're using a top 5 or even a top 3 phone camera. You will get more-than-acceptable and even great results from either. It's a case of whether you want the lower noise levels and native compatibility of the Samsung app or the extended dynamic range of the HDR+ app.

A great article that shows photos from both in different scenarios with a slider to switch between the XL 2 and S9+ version of the photo is located here: http://www.businessinsider.com/samsu...parison-2018-3

replies.text:
Honestly, I'd be happy with either.
They're among the crème de la crème of smartphone cameras and unless you're that bad or purposely trying to, it's really difficult to get a bad shot out of either.
If I had to choose, probably the S9+ because it's more versatile for me, but if I chose the Pixel, I'd be very happy with it as well

title: S9+ screen dimmed out with bright 70%

thread.text:
Today, in bright sun light the screen was black. At home , in a dark room I could see very faint text and was able to open settings. There the brightness was about 70%. I touched it to change the setting and instantly the screen was fully lit. 
Is there something wrong with this phone?

replies.text: Autobrightness in Android nowadays isn't like autobrightness on any other OS. As you make adjustments to the brightness, the phone remembers what you chose and applies those same settings in the future. It has to learn you before it will set it the way you want.
I had never set the brightness and auto us on. In the car, at first it was fine. I put it down to drive, and when I picked it up the screen was black.

That's a very misguided title. The only way that could be considered to be true, by their own standards, is if zoom is the most important quality of a smartphone. On all the aspects of photography that actually matter, the P2XL beats it hands down. That's shown in DXO's own numbers. There's a good thread about it, but the S9+ is absolutely not the best camera on a smartphone - it merely has the highest combined score so far, based on the new criteria which heavily favors having multiple cameras as opposed to a single lens. So there is now less emphasis on image quality and more emphasis on the more sensational and also more trivial aspects of photography that are enhanced by having a second lens.
Everyone said DXO was full of it when they scored the P2XL above everything else... either they were or they weren't. If they were, then they're just as full of it now. The fact is, as was realized then, is that the combined score is meaningless. It's the individual scores that actually give us good information and if you look at those scores, the P2XL trounces the S9+.
I agree with this one hundred percent. Whether or not it works for me is separate from DXO marks reviews. I've got the phone in hand with a case and some accessories. I want to love it.

You can go back further than that. When the V20 came out, they ranked it high but not the best even though real world use begged to differ. That's when it was discovered that DxO only tests in auto mode (like every other review), which meant they also encountered LG's overly aggressive noise reduction that hurts image quality.
While yes, knowing a camera's abilities in auto mode is important, it's not really judging the hardware due to the software programming. If you used manual mode to save as RAW files, the V20 is able to do much better and several people called DxO out on it at the time. If you're going to be scoring a camera, you need to at least separate hardware from software results.
V20 is a great example. Really good hardware with terrobad auto software. Shooting in manual mode it's a beast.
I doubt very much it trounces anything much less the S9+. The S9+ scored a 104 to the Pixel's 99 so I guess in your world 99 is better than 104.

No; but in my world reading is important. Have you looked at the sub scores? Do you have any idea what the sub scores mean? Do you have any idea what I wrote in the quote that you just responded to? Your response indicates that the answer to all three of those questions is no. If I'm mistaken and one of the answers is yes, then you did a terrible job of representing your argument.
Do you know what the overall score is? If the Pixel trounces EVERYTHING why did the S9+ get a better overall score? And why did they rate it the best smartphone camera ?

I dunno, I suppose I and others answered that already. I suppose you could read it and answer your own question. Also, pay attention a little to the straw man you're creating to argue against - because no one has said that the Pixel trounces EVERYTHING.

These scores are just the combined score in all categories. We can argue all day long on what beats what. Everyone sees something different. If you prefer the pixel cool. No harm. It Does win in different categories. But the overall combined score is what it is. Why go back and forth.

they're a weighted average with an obvious bias towards zoom and bokeh, so much so that they overcome exposure, color, contrast, etc. we don't know the exact weights, but it's obvious that it is biased in favor of dual cameras.

Was it a serious issue that made using the device very frustrating and did your device lead you to believe that most or all of the devices have that issue? From reading through the threads here and having seen quite a few of these devices, my impression is the opposite - that the issue is rarely drastic, doesn't appear as a problem on most devices and seems to only appear when people are specifically looking for it, typically with an all white screen, such as on Google Now and when held at extreme angles.

Very much so. I couldn't stand looking at it with white background screens, no extreme angles required. I'm being honest here, it was really bad on mine. I don't doubt that some are better than others, but the consensus has been that the 2 XL has a blue tint issue.

I don't doubt your experience at all, just whether or not it is statistically normal. That consensus is based on early reprinting of one reviewer's review unit. I have seen the blue tint myself, just not any worse than other comparable devices.

Agreed. FWIW, I loved mine so much other than the screen and was sad to return it. But I'm rocking a Pixel 2 instead now, and love it.
Another FWIW, Google's VP of Engineering has said the blue shift was a design decision based on hardware limitations of the screen:
"The slight blue tint is inherent in the display hardware and only visible when you hold the screen at a sharp angle. All displays are susceptible to some level of color shift (e.g. red, yellow, blue) when viewing from off angles due to the pixel cavity design."
“Similar to our choice with a cooler white point, we went with what users tend to prefer and chose a design that shifts blue.”
So I think the lottery is not whether you get blue shift, but how severe it is and whether it bothers you.
I also think that all amoled have blue (or other) shift, but the severity varies - and THAT is the QC problem.

I weighed pros and cons, and the screen issue worried me. I pulled the trigger and got the Pixel 2XL. Is there blue tint? Sure, do I notice it in day to day use? Nope. I very rarely if ever, view my screen at any angle other than straight on. I am so glad I made the decision to get it. I for one hate the oversaturated look that seems to be what everyone loves on the Samsung screen. But that is my preference.

I'm going to throw a little monkey wrench into this conversation just because it's something that's bugging me. I'm typing this on a PC that has a very carefully calibrated monitor for color (I run an online shop, and color reproduction from my photo stage to screen/real life is very, very important -- I also shoot with a DSLR most of the time).
What I've noticed is that on my screen, your Pixel 2 XL photos are yellow. I mean some of them are really, really yellow/greenish in color, while the comparable S9 shots appear to be much better on white balance. Just an observation. 
The last 2 outdoor shots you posted, though, appear to be perfect (presumably, from your post, these were taken with the Pixel 2). 
Interestingly, from some of the reviews I've read, this makes sense. I don't remember where I read it, but one of the camera reviews that compared the S9+ to the Pixel 2 showed the S9+ had generally better auto white balance than the Pixel.
I haven't tested the ffc on my S9 because I just don't do selfies. I do, however, do a lot of product photography and I sometimes snap quick pics with my phone camera. The S9 in this capacity so far, seems quite good for that -- far better color and detail than my old S7 camera had.
Again, just some observations. I realize you are mostly talking about the ffc, and that's probably the thing I care least about on my new phone.

I think it's a pretty safe bet that I'll be returning to Samsung this year from my current Nexus 6P. I tried "The Stock Experiment" after using an international variant S3 before it, and found that I'm bored by stock Android. Despite its speed (which is starting to slow a bit on the 6P), there's nothing to stock. What cemented it for me was my disappointment with Google, in having the gall to ask consumers to pay $1000+ when all is said and done, for IMHO, the inferior hardware of the Pixel 2 XL as a showcase for their software. No thanks.
The question now is, do I go with the S9+, or the Note 9? I'm leaving out the Note 8 because, as a female, I have smaller hands and hate the placement of the fingerprint sensor. Now, if you're one who has no use for the S Pen, this won't apply to you, but here is my thinking. The way I see it, the release of the S line of phones is like a beta test. Those that buy it are basically getting a template of a device with features on it that are set to be on the next Note as well, along with anything else Samsung decides to add to sweeten the package. When you think about it, it makes sense, given that the Note line is Samsung's premiere flagship. No other company has even dared to bring a comparable device to the table (no, not even the LG Stylo 😂).
So, the "First World Problems" question I ask is, do I go for the S9+ when it undoubtedly drops in price this summer, or do I wait for the Note 9 to be released in August/September? I've never had a Note, so I don't know how important the S Pen would be to me, but if I'm going to spend $1000+ when all is said and done, including applicable taxes, accessories and protection plan, I may as well get the most bang for my buck, no? Whether I need it or not, it is a comfort to know that the S Pen is there, should I need to use it. And I certainly don't take spending $1000+ lightly.
This is definitely a tough call, considering I'm really liking the Lilac Purple and Coral Blue colors, and Samsung made the adjustments they needed to make with the fingerprint sensor placement and the addition of the stereo speakers. I'm hoping that the audio through a good pair of ear buds will at least be comparable to the audio from the LG V30 quad DAC, or HTC BoomSound. I also hope the battery life and standby time is good. Those two things will be the deciding factors for me. One thing's certain, that whichever I go with, I'll be getting an unlocked Exynos variant to use on T-Mobile.

I never understood the S vs Note question. Do you need an S Pen? No? Get an S series and save money. Anything the next Note has the next S will have or better anyway, except for S Pen features. If you don't use the S Pen, the Note is a waste of a $200 premium.

replies.text: I laugh when people keep flapping between S and Note line. And then laugh even harder when someone says they are upgrading from Note 8 to S9+. Totally different lines of phones. Wish people stop comparing both.

They are very similar phones though, other than the pen, for some of us the pen is a nice extra, it is very useful sometimes and make things easier but I can type notes or draw with with my finger, some others NEED the pen and take handwriting notes on a daily basis so the S line or any other phone is out of the question but other than the pen they are very very similar

Heh, I upgraded from the Note 8 to S9+ (and previously from the S8+ to Note 8) but yeah I see your point. Having said that, the two lines of phones seem to be converging these days. Previously the Note was where Samsung tried out new hardware and features with their power user customers before releasing them to a more general audience via the S line. Nowadays, it seems like each Note is just an incremental improvement on the previous S phone, and vice versa. I mean, my Note 8 is basically just an S8+ with an S-Pen and a dual camera (though I must say the dual camera is a major improvement).
Generally it would be financially unwise to do what I do. But if you're on something like T-Mobile's JOD program, it doesn't make financial sense to not upgrade as often as possible. You're basically getting to trade in a used phone for up to two-thirds of its retail value.

I get this inkling that you don't like your note 8? Lol
Jokes aside. My iPhone filled family requests I use my note 8 for pics all the time over theirs. They seem to like the results more than their iphone 6, 7 and 8. Is there another phone you've used with better night shots? Are you just assuming the S9 does better?
Serious questions. Not trying to defend note 8.

Theoretically the S9 will take better pictures than the Note 8. The embedded DRAM in the camera is touted as a game changer in camera tech even before the S9 announced it had it. Sony announced this new sensor almost a month before the S9 was announced. The increased aperture also lets in more light then before so it will be better for low light photography.
Of course however we still cannot account for the software processing, but hardware wise the S9 hsd greater potential than the Note 8.

The biggest gains here are hidden within the SD845 : multi-frame processing. Those other features are incremental, but this will the source of most of the improvements that people will see with the camera. Everyone is finally catching on that Google's now 4 year old approach is the way to go if you want consistently great pictures in every situation.
Yup, but remember that the software can only do as much as the hardware allows. So I don't believe the changes in the camera hardware is just incremental, especially with the right software.
Nah... MFP takes quality and separates it from hardware. Take crappy cameras and turn them good, good cameras get great.

It definitely has more potential in terms of hardware.
But its software that's probably going to complete the picture. I think Google showed last year how great software can go around hardware limitations and even complement great hardware.
The following shots are shot using the HDR+ port on the Note8. They look pretty good.
Those are ALL awesome shots!

Thanks
HDR+ is just one of those things that really just works as intended.
It makes a bad camera more than usable and makes a good camera great
The photos are not really that amazing TBH. Perhaps the photos quality got degraded when sharing in the forum. Very normal photo quality.

They do get degraded when uploading due to compression being applied in order to save bandwidth.
I'll likely share a proper Google Photos album with better examples, especially in HDR situations

Those shots look pretty impressive to me: vibrant and full of color. The combination of the native camera in Pro mode and the ported Google Pixel software make the Note8's photography game nice and strong. I'm content with all the N8 has to offer .

I do have an X and Note 8 and both take ok-ish night shots. That said, I don't really take a lot of night shots.

replies.text: Not that you SHOULD HAVE TO but do you disable/uninstall unwanted apps? Do you have location services set to High Accuracy instead of Battery Saver? Choose Battery Saver unless you're actively using mapping. Are Bluetooth and NFC enabled even when not in use? While I like Android, I know that I have to tune these things if I want the best experience. That's the difference, for me, between Android and iOS but I don't mind too much.

I feel I have to fine-tune iOS when I use it as well. The default settings for most things are annoying so have to fine-tune / set it up just like I would an Android phone. Android just has way more freedom when it comes to apps doing things so therefore may have a few more toggles due to extra permissions versus iOS where you would simply say "Oh it can only do X but not Y" so no real options except for X.
Unwanted / carrier bloat apps are always the worst on Android .. but if you are getting a Samsung it is to be expected.

It could be -- some people get "disable crazy" from what I have seen over the years. They want to disable every little thing they don't use but don't realize they are disabling some stuff that is actually hurting them.
I personally just used the default menu when I had Samsung. I disabled all the carrier bloat and a few other things and that was it. I didn't ever dive into the app to do it since disabling those other 10 things to eek out an extra 1 hour of battery life aren't worth it to me. thread.text:
You can view running packages and services in bk 
And it is an eye opener to see how much memory things use, edge display for example seems to use a lot.

replies.text:
Using memory isn't bad though. Android tries to fill up RAM. Everyone compares RAM usage being high as bad but that is really a Windows thing. A Windows PC should only have so much used depending on what is open whereas Android is different. It tries to fill up RAM and it will free up RAM when it needs it for other tasks.
Trying to manage and clear it actually does the exact opposite of what the OS is trying to do. I have never used bk disabler, only disabled a few "bloat" apps from the normal menu, and my previous Samsung phones never had horrid battery. Sure some went all out and had a screenshot list and maybe got an extra hour versus me but not worth for me. The maybe 1 hour I get more of life along with possibly disabling something incorrectly to cause even worse drain (that you then have to troubleshoot) is just way too much headache for me.
I look at it like if I have to go through ALL that just to get "good" battery life then Samsung really dropped the ball super hard on their version of Android. From my past usage without going disable-crazy... I always had good life. Maybe not 5 days 36 hours SOT like some go for (obviously exaggerated) but I could last through an entire day and had no issues. Heavier days I charged at work, truck, home etc. The 20-30 min drive I would do at the end of the day would warrant me a good hunk of battery % from the quick charge so I truly never worried.
Thank you, this needs to be said about 1000 times.

Windows fills up memory as unused RAM is simply a waste, not only that but tasks are speeded up by having them in RAM rather than on a hard disk. Windows also frees up memory when required, so it functions in exactly the same way as Android does.
I can def. say mine doesn't. If I sit with nothing open.. barely any RAM is used. If I open a game it gets used. It doesn't just sit and fill the RAM like Android.

I had forgotten the name of it on Windows. It's called SuperFetch and does two things, speed up boot times and caches frequently used applications to memory to help them launch faster.
I believe that the amount used is the committed value in Task Manager.
This might help explain it, not sure how reliable it is as a source though:http://mobile.osnews.com/story.php/2...it_Works_Myths

I would have to check once home but pretty sure that is off for me. Any indexing / fetching is not on for my SSD.
Either way my point still stands about Android. Constantly clearing it actually goes against what the OS is trying to do so therefore it will just keep using more CPU to keep trying to re-build the stuff in RAM.
Jerry has a beautiful article on it (below) for anyone that wants to read.https://www.androidcentral.com/ram-w...-shouldnt-care

You wouldn't need it for a system with an SSD anyway as the storage is fast enough, this is only beneficial for mechanical HDDs.
Jerry has one point wrong, Windows DOESN'T keep the RAM open and free for an app that needs it as it clears the RAM when an app needs it then fills the RAM when it's no longer needed. Just look in task manager and you'll see what I mean.

I literally do. Sitting idle I have barely any RAM used. It does not even come close to filling the RAM....
FYi - I build my own rigs and am not a novice on PCs so me saying earlier that I know mine doesn't means I actually know as in I have checked and watched .
I've worked in IT for 20 years and built many of my own machines, so I know exactly what I'm talking about. Like I said, check Task Manager!!!

Again -- Already have checked it. been there, done that, got the T-Shirt .
We can agree to disagree. I will believe what I know of my system & trust others just like Jerry since I believe he knows what he is talking about .
Good day sir!

thread.text:
That’s honestly weird.
On my recent holiday, I used my Note8 a crap ton and it didn’t die until late at night.
Did Sammy somehow mess up with standby battery on the S9?
But if it's running it also using power too right? Not because it's using memory but just because it is running?

replies.text:
By clearing the RAM the OS tries to re-load it back up. You then clear it again and it re-loads it back up. You're wasting more power by fighting the OS since it keeps using the processor to get stuff loaded back into RAM.
Everything uses power. Things sitting in power isn't necessarily a bad thing. The only time it would be bad would be a rogue app doing something malicious, bugging out, or something of that nature. Most apps will go dormant and just sit there until called.

thread.text: protip: charge your phone at night whilst sleeping instead of obsessing over standby battery drain. problem solved. you're welcome.

replies.text: I just charge phones before bed and I am usually good in the morning.

Charging overnight can actually reduce battery life as Li-Ion batteries should really have small charges throughout the day and not be charged to 100%.
So instead of obsessing over standby drain just plug it into the mains whenever you like.
I've read this isn't true of smartphones. That they manage rate of charge to prevent over charging and damage. https://twitter.com/verge/status/903...286249473?s=19
While true it's more the repeated charges from 95% up to 100% overnight that can degrade the battery. You won't notice it immediately but over time it becomes noticeable.

It's called a trickle.
The closer it gets to 100%, the slower it will be. That's why charging seems really quick from dead to around 50% but after that, it slows down the closer it gets to full.

The Trickle charge technology has been around a long time, used in 12 volt car battery chargers for decades. I use "Ampere Meter Pro" app to monitor charge differences between wireless charger and 110 adapters. The app has several metrics it monitors, most useful for me is the phone temperature and voltage. Fast charging runs the temp up to 90 degrees, 10 higher than 110 adapters, (doesn't seem good for long term battery life). This thread seems to have wondered around a bit, like my grandkids.

QFT
Charging overnight is far from a protip... Avoiding this practice is the real protip

Hence why there are more options when setting up various functions on Android. iPhone is super restrictive on background processes. It is a double edge sword .. better battery life but less functionality depending on what you are trying to do.
