Overall I guess I am questioning the value and all the current breed of droids have their compromises and I just need to pick the one I prefer. I am leaning towards returning it and picking up either the 2XL or V30 again, or maybe I need to look further afield to other brands? One thing I do know as I post this on my iPhone is that I am now every much an android person!

title: Notification sounds when on a call

thread.text: I have an issue with missing new text messages because I don't hear a notification sound when I'm on a phone call. I have had this problem since my S8 and have been looking for a solution. I just got an S9+ and noticed there is an option for an LED light to flash to let you know when you have new messages, emails, etc... Does anyone know of a way where I can have a sound go off to notify me of a received message while I'm on a phone call? My girlfriend has a Motorola G5+ or something like that (not sure of the model) and her phone can vibrate or have a sound notify her of a new message. I would like to have that. Thanks in advance.

Depends on the app you're using. Textra, for instance, does have an option to play a sound while in-call. I don't see that option in the stock messaging app, however, but it should vibrate while in-call I believe.

replies.text: I'd probably have to have my phone on vibrate because if the ringtone volume is on, it doesn't vibrate or make a sound. I'm going to try Textra and see if that works. Thank you man

thread.text: just tested mine on a phone call and it works, but the option has been removed from the stock messaging app

I think i may have found a similar option located in the settings for phone calls that allows you to turn on/off such notifications during calls.
To either enable or disable the notifications do the following,
On the home screen tap the Green phone button, 
press the 3 Dots on the top right corner, 
select "Settings"
select "Call Alerts"
at the bottom of this menu screen you will find the option "Notify During Calls"
Check to see if this is enabled.
I hope this helps.

title: Moving photos to albums but they're still showing In main pictures

thread.text: So i got the new s9+ I put all my old photos on from my old phone (8000) now they are all in a funny order so I tried moving them all into folders so the main picture bit in my gallery is empty for all my new photos when I put them into albums it said move so I expected them to be gone from my gallery is there a way to do this? Thanks

Gallery shows all pictures listed in the Media Scan database. Media Scan scans the entire phone when it starts (or when you do a media-related thing, like taking a picture). So Gallery shows all the pictures on the phone. Show the pictures in one picture app but not another picture app? No, that all use the same database. (If all you've done so far is copy them and move them around, either restart the phone or run an app like media.Re.Scan, to rebuild the database so it shows the current state of things.)
Welcome to Android Central! Are you using the stock Gallery app, or the Google Photos app?

title: The S9's display shifts color temperature a little bit off-axis (as most OLEDs do)

thread.text:
Now, don't get sassy. If you know OLED, you'd know that color shifting is a trait of OLED and every panel will have this phenomenon, of varying levels.
But because the Pixel 2 XL got everyone noticing, I thought I'd just let everyone know.
Does the S9's display shift color? Yes. How significantly? Depends on the unit but I've tried every one on the show floor and none shifted as badly to the point where it's annoying, and certainly not nearly as bad as the worst P2XL unit I've used shown below. 
P2XL for comparison 
Now let's just rest on this, okay? All OLEDs shift color at certain angles. Hell, my Note shifts red at the same angles. Unless it's really bad, it's not really indicative of a defect and if you stopped noticing or are okay with it, that's fine.
Just checked mine. It's almost non existent. My Note 8 is much worse. It shifts to pink/red even slightly off angle.

replies.text:
Mine does too.
It's not even really that noticeable tbh.
It's really noticeable on my Note 8. It's barely noticeable on my S9+. I'm loving the S9+ so far.

thread.text: It shouldn’t be extreme though. Some color shifting is notmal

replies.text:
Minor shifts are normal.
Extreme ones aren't and unless you somehow can live with them, you should try getting one with less drastic shifting

thread.text: Love my S9 so far. My old S8 had pink edges and overall pink hue when in any mode other than Adaptive. My Pixel 2 XL has mild blue shift. S9 just has very minimal blue edges and shift when at an extreme angle, not a hint of pink anywhere. Also the basic color profile looks perfect and same colors as my Pixel and iPhone X. Very happy with my S9 screen.

replies.text:
I returned my pre-order S8+ for the nasty pink edges. The replacement they sent me was even worse. The entire display was off. I had people comment and ask me what was wrong with it.
That one went back also, lol. I gave up on the S8+.

Does anyone experience burn-in from the navigation bar? I got my Galaxy S9+ on the 12th of March and the home button has already burnt in and can be seen in some conditions. I've set the bar to auto-hide but have set the AOD to appear with the square icon for the home button at the bottom. Not sure if this has caused the burn in cause I know the square should move places a bit to prevent such issues. Before the S9+ I had a S7 edge and had absolutely no traces of burn in. So dissapointed from Samsung, a huge mistake to put a navigation bar on an OLED screen. Few years back when I had the Galaxy Nexus nearly everything has burnt in the display, e.g. app icons, navigation bar, status bar. That was the time when I swore I would never buy a Galaxy phone again. When the S7 edge came out though I couldn't resist it and I told myself I would never buy a phone different than a Galaxy, and now I don't know how to feel. I can only imagine what this display would look like after a year or two of usage given the fact that a small button shifting positions managed to burn in for a few days.

replies.text:
You can always check with AT&T. Don't ask them if there is no downside, because they will tell you that OF COURSE there is a downside. But, if you use HD voice or wifi calling ask if those features will work on the unlocked phone.
Going unlocked means that you get to move to a different carrier more easily, if you want. It's also often a bit less expensive if you can manage the full price up front, and you can often avoid the wait imposed by the carrier (due to their testing) for updates.

title: S9+ Camera isn't horrible at all. In fact...

thread.text:
This is more in line with what I've experienced putting both cameras side by side. Pixel 2XL is sharper with slightly more detail, but the S9+ holds it's own and just looks outstanding.
Can't wait to get mine!

replies.text: Was anyone thinking it was going to be horrible?

thread.text: Interesting comparison.

Seems a lot of bias in the first place, since most of the critics are XL2 or iPX owners on different forums. This is in contrast to most photography centric reviews and media reviews in general. They both take great pics, so calling the S9 not good/bad seems disingenuous.

replies.text: My real world shooting with Sammy's since the S7 has been lackluster. My three year old iPhone consistently took more accurate and better quality photos than my Note 8 in all but the best lightning conditions. I think there's far more bias toward the Korean manufacturer than there is toward Pixel owners. Samsung still hasn't nailed portrait mode and it's ability to capture and process photos outside of an object or person being completely still leaves much to be desired.

Samsung tends to prioritize pleasure over authenticity.
Granted, they've toned it down over the years but compare it to an iPhone (8 and X are more vibrant though compared to the 7) and the Pixel and the difference is clear.
It's not bad, but it's a different approach. I've personally stuck to using the Pixel 2 camera on the Note8 and aside from being a tad grainier due to less aggressive conventional NR (which I'm totally fine with), I preferred its output. It's almost always closer to what I see in reality with vastly improve DR. It's definitely a top 5 or even a top 3 camera so far. I don't think Samsung knocked it out of the park with this one (honestly, I don't think we'd notice that much given how good phone cameras have become) but they certainly have not regressed. It's still a great camera and a very solid improvement over the Note8.
Yeah okay

thread.text:
That's sort of par for the course with Samsung releases. A week ago all we heard was negativity regarding this phone. Everything from "meh" to "horrible photos" to weird comparisons to the Pixel 2XL. Now that people are actually getting these phones in their hands, we're now hearing how terrific this phone and it's camera actually are.
Your're right in that I think there was a lot of early biases going on to try and steer folks towards a certain other phone.
I don’t think anyone said it was horrible to begin with...

replies.text: Exactly I'm not sure who is saying the camera is horrible. Sure there may be few posts here and there which will be there for any phone. At least all the reviews, hands on and other reports I have read is this is a great camera. Personal experience is also that it's a great camera. Does it blow other camera on iPhone X or Pixel 2? No but definitely top of the stack and comes down to preference.

Samsung tends to prioritize pleasure over authenticity.
Granted, they've toned it down over the years but compare it to an iPhone (8 and X are more vibrant though compared to the 7) and the Pixel and the difference is clear.
It's not bad, but it's a different approach. I've personally stuck to using the Pixel 2 camera on the Note8 and aside from being a tad grainier due to less aggressive conventional NR (which I'm totally fine with), I preferred its output. It's almost always closer to what I see in reality with vastly improve DR. It's definitely a top 5 or even a top 3 camera so far. I don't think Samsung knocked it out of the park with this one (honestly, I don't think we'd notice that much given how good phone cameras have become) but they certainly have not regressed. It's still a great camera and a very solid improvement over the Note8.

thread.text: Yeah.. Samsung S9 Plus has incredible camera which offers dual aperture range f/1.5 and f/2.4 and also its DXO mark rate is 99. Therefore, it's been proved world's best camera in smartphone segments till date..

replies.text:
Well, about that DxO score.....
.....it's a tad misleading due to its aggregate. Comparing it to the last champ, the Pixel 2, the S9+ mainly wins in zoom and noise (latter should have been weighted more IMO). Pixel was better in exposure and others alongside video.
Not saying the S9 camera is bad. Again, it's great and it's probably a top 3 shooter. Just that we shouldn't take aggregate DxO scores as a definitive source to judge camera quality. It's like a benchmark.

thread.text: The DXO Mark is very misleading. You need to look at the scores. I took a picture of my son with the S9+ and Pixel 2 XL and the Pixel has way more definition and detail.

replies.text: And I also take pictures with both phones and the S9+ is way sharper
No way. Here's two pictures of the same bedsheets. Pixel is way sharper.

thread.text: Here's two shots of the same dragon. Once again, the Pixel has way more detail.
This is the S9
The Pixel 2 look a bit over sharpened. The S9 looks closer to the actual colors. Weird to say that, but that’s what I’m seeing
The S9+ is way sharper with my pictures
And that's why none of this matters. Everyone sees something a little differently. Everyone's eyes are different. Everyone has different tastes.

title: Samsung giveth with the S8 and Samsung taketh away with the S9

thread.text:
Seems like with the new S9+ there's a bunch of little things either missing, don't work as good as they or just seem off compared to last years model.
Here's a small list I've noticed so far. Correct me if I'm wrong.
- Can't seem to find the option to force full screen in apps and games anymore. I had to go into settings and flip the switch to force full screen instead of hitting the full screen button during minimize.
- No way to customize text notification sounds for contacts now.
- No way to customize the background wallpaper for the text conversations.
- Netflix on the S9+ is horribly darker than the S8+. Some scenes are almost unwatchable even on full screen brightness. Ran the S8+ and S9+ side by side for comparison, it's night and day.
- Had a few freeze issues when jumping in and out of the camera or after recording video. 
- Swiftkey has a scaling issue with the keyboard on the S9+. It's HUGE on medium setting. 
- Opened the color adjust option on both S8+ and S9+ (under screen mode). The scaling of their vegetable example picture scales differently on both phones.
- Always on display on the S9+ added new clocks. But then removed the clock backgrounds at the same time.
Anyone else come across more?

None yet, but the custom text notifications, lack of text background options, and the swiftkey thing have been grinding my gears all day since I switched from the S7. Knowing who is texting while I'm at a job is a pretty huge thing for me as it means the difference between stopping what I'm doing to respond or finish up.
I'm on SwiftKey beta and am not seeing scaling issues on my s9+. I tried every size option, they all look/work OK.
For the next notification issue, I assume this is a limitation of the Samsung message app for the s9? I use Textra and can (still) set custom contact notifications.

The custom text tomes was lost on my S9+ too so when I returned it and kept my S8+ I figured it would be there but the Oreo update took the feature away. You have to use a 3rd party app to customize text tones now.

thread.text:
Mod Note
This was posted in the Pixel 2 area -- moving to the S9 area.

I preordered and got cold feet due to a lot ofvthe poor or mediocre reviews on everything from battery life to camera quality. I absolutely love my S9+. Maybe I'm not the best judge of the phone because I'm coming from a 5yr old Droid Maxx and surely any newer phone is going to be better, but so far the S9+ is running super smooth, battery life is great, the features are excellent, the rear cameras are amazing, and I even like Bixby (better than OK Google). My only real complaint so far is that the front camera should have received an overhaul because it is definitely lacking compared to the rear cameras...but I don't take selfies so ultimately I don't care. If I would have been coming from an S8, Pixel 2 XL, or iPhone 8/X then I might not see the benefits of switching to the S9+.

you'll see a lot more hate and issues with Samsung's new releases cause they sell millions more than any other android device. You might have 10 people on here that buy the pixels compared 10 thousand that buy a galaxy 🤣

replies.text: I know what you're saying but I'm thinking the numbers are not super accurate. Lol

thread.text: I guess a lot of the drama comes from the different factors such as the high prices. They may not be as high as Apple, but people hold them to such a high standard.

I'm not seeing any battery issues, however it's the weekend & I'm not using the phone like I would during a work week. I'll wait 7 days (per the Battery Usage setting on the phone) before I make a declarative statement about battery life (unlike most people, who seem to be jumping to conclusions before the first 24 hours is over).

It's normal.
Every phone launch is like this.

I have used Samsung phones for years and from time to time there are minor issues, but overall a nice experience! ...I recently pickup the Samsung galaxy S9plus, coming from the note 8, I love this phone, improved sound and picture quality ! In my opinion, Samsung has knocked it out of the park!

thread.text:
Samsung makes one of the best internet browsers. I use Samsung's browser over chrome. 
With everything else, I use Google's version mostly.

Samsung Pay IMO is better than Google Pay. 
I use Samsung internet because of 
Samsung Pass. Chrome bookmarks sync as well.
Samsung Calendar syncs almost instantly with Google Calendar. 
I use both Samsung Notes & Google Keep. Keep can be used across multiple platforms, but I like Samsung Notes' mobile interface better. 
I do use both Google Asst. & Bixby. Different uses for each. 
I'm fully invested in the Google ecosystem, but for the most parts Samsungs apps sync well with Google services.

I use Chrome on both my desktop and phone, so I'm sticking with Chrome. I'm still trying to find a good notes app to import my PDFs from my LG G6 notes. Samsung Notes isn't able to import from PDFs. I've been a huge fan of QuickPic for a long time. I mostly use that and Google Photos. I like being able to see which pictures are actually on my device as opposed to being in the cloud.
I prefer Samsung's apps over Google's especially Samsung's internet browser.

I never really used cloud storage until my SD card corrupted losing a year's worth of pix (including the first 6 months of my son). I'm a fan of onedrive so sync to that but the unlimited photo storage with Google Photos is making me take a relook. 
also linked to onedrive, I use OneNote and office for documents etc. haven't quite ventured into Google docs territory yet, but wife has a Chromebook and I don't like Microsoft's new subscription based price tag for office, so might give docs a go. Samsung notes just seems like throwing another option in just for the sake of it

I also prefer Samsung apps over Googles. That's why when reviewers complain about duplicate apps I laugh. I actually prefer Samsung apps. I hate the Google messaging app and Calendar app. Their ugly. Samsung adds more functionality with their apps that I enjoy.
I use Google's apps for the most part as I wasn't any transition to a different brand to be as seamless as possible. I only use Samsung Pay over Android Pay due to the MST.

I also prefer Samsung's apps over Google's. I did have a go at all of them over the years. I also download the Google ones when they get major updates, but so far by my book they're all inferior to Samsung's versions with the possible exception of Keep. But then I use neither Keep nor Samsung Notes so that's moot.
Samsung has always tried to dominate the world of Android, pushing its alternative key applications. I do not like it very much.

I use a combination of Samsung and Google apps. I like Samsung pay and health. I only use Google Assistant instead of bixby. I actually go through phases where I use Gmail or Samsung's mail app. one feature available in Samsung's mail app not found in Gmail is the ability to snooze emails, which I love. however, Gmail makes it quicker to manage message in bulk. I also prefer the Google keyboard even though the Samsung keyboard is good.

title: Galaxy S9- 4 or 6 GB of RAM on the Regular S9

thread.text:
Hi,
I’ve read a few articles saying that the regular S9 is going to have 4gb of RAM and the Plus is going to have 6gb of RAM.
Any thoughts on this? I’m not the biggest camera fan so I’m ok with a single lense but that RAM will make a difference IMHO. I prefer a smaller device for one handed use, so I hope they go with 6gb of RAM across the board.

Even a small amount of RAM is enough to take gigantic pictures. If you create a picture that's larger than what's left of 4GB, you could probably blow it up to 16 feet by 9 feet and not find any break in it with a microscope. (4GB would make smaller spots than silver does on film.)

4GB of RAM is more than enough to handle multiple apps running concurrently. Plus, the new chip will be a lot faster so don't think you'll notice any lag with 4GB of RAM.
If you're planning to play heavy gaming, 6GB of RAM will surely help.
I am planning to go for the + because I like the bigger screen size.
Not seen one credible study showing a significant change in 4GB to 6GB. Seems people are thinking in the PC convention. Not same method of memory management.

thread.text: It seems a great device with a weak battery performance
just curious but what is the best display to have set for every day use? I'm new to Galaxy

if you search on YouTube there are a bunch of new battery comparisons with the s9+. I'm consistently getting 5.5 to 6 hours of SoT on my Note 8. I have about 140 apps, ATT locked version. I disabled almost all the bloat. With AOD on standby loss of about 1% loss per hour. I would disagree that Samsung has general bad battery life . I have an Mate 9 as well to compare.
Android system and Android OS @18% is insane, means rogue app....
Batteries take several charges to be conditioned properly anyway so bad battery life on a 3 day old phone is to be expected.

I have a SD845 S9+ (delivered today).. Battery seems to be very good. Don't have enough info on standby drain but don't see heavy drain. I did the following.
1) Setup from scratch.
2) After updating to the latest firmware I reset the phone
3) Disabled a few apps & Bixby, using BX Actions to remap bixby button
4) No AOD, no iris or facial scanning just the fingerprint sensor
5) Charged the phone after turning it on, setup the phone while plugged in.
I'm at 1hr 48 min usage 84% battery remaining. I used the phone for browsing and some apps here n there, set them up, not heavy usage. I know I'm happy that I am on the good side of battery (I OCD on battery usage :P ) and seeing stats like this would make someone who has bad battery go crazy, I'm posting this so that one could try these and see if the battery gets better.

Many purchase Samsung for its features. Now we are told to get decent battery life it is best to disable as many features as possible. If I wanted a featureless phone I would buy a Google phone in the first place. Older versions of Android would tell you which apps were using the battery. Now too many are included in "Android system" so we have no idea what is going on. This is a bad thing.
The real source of the problem imo are the changes in Android that prevent us seeing specifically which apps are eating the battery. This isn't Samsung's fault. I suspect providers prefer that users don't find their bloatware as a proven source of problems. Android now hides it nicely.

replies.text: You can blame that on consumers wanting thinner devices (per consumed marketing). Aesthetics over practical useage.

I was able to squeeze 7.5 hrs of SOT in 47 hours after the first charge. SD845.. 22 mins of calls, mostly browsing, didn't play a lot of videos.. took a few snaps and played around with AR emoji.. standby seems 3-4 hours/ 1%.
I don't use AOD, Bixby, Google Assistant & Iris / facial unlock. I'll use AOD if/when I get an update that makes AOD work with proximity sensor that allows me to wave and make the phone display the AOD content (like I used to have on my old Nokias). The rest not important for me.

I found a couple of apps to tweak on my end to improve this as well. Hopefully it gets even better. Very happy so far.
My wife's S9+ runs all day without any battery issues. But she is not a fan of the edge screen, so that's turned off.
I went yesterday and today, no charger and it went dead in 47 hours with about 3.5 hrs SOT, just insane battery life. I'm really cautious about what's syncing tho...

thread.text:
Very strange that some of you are paying for shipping, let alone not getting free overnight. I've been on JOD for 3 years and I switch out 3 phones per year. I've never paid for shipping and it's always been free overnight. Always. S9 order last night was no exception. 
And for those still wondering why some high end models (Samsung's Plus line) require a deposit now. It's because they changed the JOD policy a while back to allow an upgrade every month if desired. The only way that made business sense for Tmo, is by requiring a deposit for the highest end phones. Makes sense. It's a bummer, but it makes sense.
Lastly, I see a lot of people on JOD concerned with how much a monthly payment is going to be. If you're on JOD, then you should be switching out phones a minimum of 3 times per year, or JOD doesn't make financial sense....so your monthly payment is somewhat meaningless, because it's always going to be in the $30-$34 range for flagships. People on JOD who are going with the Plus model and paying $120 down, need to keep that in mind. Because if you're on JOD, you really should be getting rid of this S9 or S9 plus within 3-4 months, max. Next up for me will be LG's flagship and then the Note 9. Rinse/repeat. It's amazing how many promo gifts I have racked up over the years as well. Still waiting to hear what the gift for the S9 will be. Love JOD.

replies.text: Are the promo gifts just part of JOD or do you get them with Jump too?

They have always been manufacturer gifts. Doesn't matter how you buy/lease the device. Once you get the device, you have to do the gift form submission through Samsung/LG etc.
It's a bit odd we still don't know what the gift for the S9 will be. Usually we know before pre-orders start. Hopefully it's something good this time.

I heard they are doing away with the free gifts for now because of all them being repetitive. Could be wrong but that's what I heard. Now most all the gifts are going to come with cell phone carriers doing there own promo.

I think they are doing away with them to save money.. especially from people either claiming multiple or returning the device and keeping the promos :P.
As with most things in life -- the ones who take advantage of loopholes usually ruin it for others. That is why a lot of carrier "deals" have turned into "Get $400 off!!!" then the fine print says "over 24 months via bill credits" versus an actual $400 off right at the register w/ your trade-in.

Actually it's probably more of a business decision from a financial standpoint. By distributing the money over time, the unpaid money they owe you can be invested to help generate more money. Kind of like an annuity. Insurance companies do the same thing with your insurance premiums.

Yeah get people to invest and stay if they want the full value.. whereas before they did MasterCard in a week or two for the amount. I know of people purposely swapping, getting the deal / card, and leaving the carrier the next month.
Therefore they cut someone a nice deal and didn't retain the customer.

Yeah I remember that also, I did regular free shipping like always because I've heard of people doing overnight shipping, paying that extra money (sometimes more than $20) and receiving their phone on the same day as someone who did free-shipping or pre-ordered a few days after them. 
It doesn't seem to make sense to pay for overnight shipping since all the pre-orders start shipping at the same time roughly no matter what shipping option you choose....at least with Samsung pre-orders.
Also every year I pre-order a Samsung phone I receive it the day after it ships anyway.

After trying the cameras (plural) of the S9+ at Best buy, i'm really stunned.
They have a contraption for demonstration that has a hole at the top, like a kaleidoscope, where you point the S9+'s camera, and even though it's pitch black inside, the picture comes out nicely!
Very impressive!
Big pixel size captures more light per pixel.
That contraption for demos also does some spinning tricks, where a wheel spins (like a merry go around) and you use the S9+'s super slow motion to take a video of it. then, upon playback, you slow it down and it is really special!
Good demos!

My t-mobile store has the same contraption for the s9+ camera yet they don't even have a working 9 plus. Seemed kind of stupid to me. They had a working s9, but that's not the phone with the amazing low light camera.

@accapro:
i understand your frustration and disappointment. on the other hand, it might be that their "system" might not update at the same time equally across the entire pre-order customer base.
furthermore, i don't think their batch packing and processing of the pre-orders is as refined or divided up with such refinement - what i am saying is that everyone who pre-ordered starting at 12:01AM on March 2nd through, say, the morning of March 3rd, would be put in the same "batch" are we're all equal in the eyes of the system. all of us will get processed and our phones will ship out at the same time, i.e. late Sunday night, as they often do. 
often, by Sunday night around 11pm, there'll be a lot of action with the tracking and the entire batch will leave Kentucky and will move to the various sub-hubs around the country.
so, as disappointing as it seems at this point, i am reasonably sure that it is the system that failed to update you on a timely basis as it did the rest of us. it will likely update by Sunday night when all the action takes place.
that said, there is still no excuse for your particular phone not being updated in exactly the same manner as the rest of us. why shouldn't it be updated at exactly the same time? of course it should have!

Do you have a UPS MyChoice Account...if so then follow these steps:
Go to your MyChoice Delivery Planner
Select Change Delivery
Select Deliver My Package On Another Day
Go To New Delivery Date 
Select Tuesday, 03/13/2018
Enter credit/debit card information and pay fee ($5.00)
Package should arrive on Tuesday, just like someone that paid for Next Day Air and if you do this before your package shows shipped you should be fine. 
You'll want to do this prior to Sunday evening because packages should be leaving UPS and showing delivery date information on the website and app sometime early Monday morning for Next Day Air shipments.Next Day Air: Next Business Day after shipping (i.e. Tuesday delivery)https://www.ups.com/us/en/shipping/s...t-day-air.page2nd Day Air: Second Business Day after shipping (i.e. Wednesday delivery) https://www.ups.com/us/es/shipping/s...d-day-air.page

replies.text: Don't feel bad. Remember me with the Note 8 last year and Irma? I live in Southwest Florida. Somehow my n8 was not placed onto the plane in time to RSW. So it was put on another flight the next night to Miami. Anyway, it got to Miami and then they stopped deliveries due to Irma. So it took me 6 days after Irma left for me to get my phone. The Miami warehouse was one of the last areas to get power I guess. UPS website kept saying due to a power outage there. So in total I got my Note 8 almost two weeks after everyone else who ordered from Samsung.com did thanks to UPS not loading my phone on the right flight and then Irma. Irma was at some points forecasted to hit my area as a 140mph storm so I left town for the storm surge. I was more worried about my Note 8 lol.
Holy crap...not good! I guess it's fortunate we're not in hurricane season right now.

And the Note line usually ships in early Sept which is right close to the peak of hurricane season! If Irma would have just went 20 miles north and stayed just off the Cuban coast and not weaken, South FL would have been hit with a strong cat 4, close to cat 5 probably. I know if Irma would have went just 25 miles west and made final landfall around Charlotte Harbor, Venice,or hugged the coast, my house probably would been under a few feet of water, especially if it was stronger than when it hit Marco Island.
Now watch the same thing will happen again this year when I pre order the Note 9 lol. Maybe that's telling me to get s9 plus lol.

Hope not. Glad you and your family were ok down there. And hopefully this year you get your phone quicker. You were going bonkers over the Note 8 debacle I remember. The hurricane screwed up your shipping if I recall from all the posts. Hopefully this year it goes smoother. And no hurricane.
tells you something when I was more worried about my Note 8 sitting in Miami than my house being there when I got back lol.

It tells me you most likely didn't pay for the house hence the no concern :P. I can definitely say I was way more worried about my house/family then any piece of tech in my house or on the way to my house.

These phones are addictive like a drug almost!
Back to the topic I'm still wondering how I will go with the Note 9 and if I should order from Tmobile, buy from samsung.com OR buy unlocked from samsung or best buy. They just built 2 new tmobile stores near me so hopefully they have stock on release day. We used to just have one store in my county and had to drive over 30 miles to the next one so the only store never had the phones in stock.
I haven't had bad luck ordering from samsung.com luckily. 
However, since wifi calling and visual voicemail work with tmobile on unlocked Samsungs I'm thinking going unlocked next time. I figure resale value would be a bit more too not being carrier branded.
You might recall my Note 7 return disaster with tmobile and over 3 months for a refund to the point I was ready to contact local news reporters and the attorney general over it. After that I decided to order the s8 plus and Note 8 from samsung instead of dealing with them again.
I would suggest making another topic to discuss this. This thread is more for people to talk about pre-ordering / shipping of their S9/S9+ versus where you should pre-order your next Note from.

3:16am now, no scans.

Yup, from Louisville! Glad to hear that the weather didn't prevent take off today, though I wonder if we'd have our phones already but for the poor weather conditions.
T-Mobile's website says I can expect delivery tomorrow. However, the shipments will likely go to the UPS distribution center here in the Twin Cities, MN sometime tonight. I expect it'll be in the early hours of the morning, but it's much earlier I wonder if I could pick my phone up tonight. They're open till 8 PM, so I suppose it's in the realm of possibility.
I sort of wish I'd taken Amy's advice and had the package held at UPS. However, when my Note 8 was arriving I selected this option while it was in transit, and the rescheduled delivery date was a full day later. I was able to cancel my request, but only after a lengthy phone conversation. I'm guessing this wouldn't have been an issue if I did so before the origin scan, but at the time I didn't want to risk it.
Oh well, I'll have a new phone by the end of tomorrow so no complaints!

mine arrived and just finished charging it to 100%. i guess i'm very conservative in my tech items, meaning despite all the claims of needing or not needing to first charge it to 100%, i figure it can't do it any harm, so i might as well follow the common wisdom and hopefully, get some extra minutes of battery life out of it.

So do you all think it's worth going from a note 8 to an s9+ ? Note I did not say upgrading because it's 2 separate types of phones

replies.text: I've got the Note 8. I very well may Jump to the 9+ I'm enjoying it and also have a Tab S3

Mine was one of the Note8s with freezing issues, so it was a no-brainer for me. Assuming my Note8 didn't have problems, I'd probably say it's not really worth it unless you aren't losing any money from the switch (i.e. Jump On Demand with zero down) and don't use the S-Pen that much.

I should mention that I did get a warranty replacement Note 8 - original did freeze up and had an odd Moisture Present note that wouldn't allow any charging (it wasn't moist at all). It did reboot on its own a couple of times. The replacement I've had for probably 2 months now and haven't had any real issues other than an annoying thing with messages "hanging"and circulating, before they go through sometimes - some of them take over a minute to "send".
Have been at work all day so not a LOT of work with the new 9+ but so far it's quite positive.

replies.text: Let us know how that nano liquid works, I'm done with trying screen protectors on curved screens. Went without on my note 8 and it had some noticeable scratches, but I turned it in to tmobile and they didn't say anything about them. I have the supcase with the built in screen protector for work and it seems to work pretty good. Hopefully that will minimize the scratches this time around.

How is the built in screen protector on it? How is sensitivity? I thought about getting it or the I Blason Magma case for my Note 8. I know it used a different material than most built in protectors due to the curved screen. The Defender for the s7 edge had a thicker material due to the curve. No dust ever got under it because it was so tight, but touch sensitivity was just terrible with it.

I only used it for a couple hours, but it's much improved over the note 8 version. You'll probably need to turn on screen sensitivity, but I think it's worth the money. I bought it with the buy 2 get 30% off deal on Amazon. Got 2 cases for $26.

thread.text:
Bummer big time: i have the S9+
even though Samsung Smart Transfer went well and Google resync'ing went well too, out of the blue, when everything just sync'ed properly and i seem to be able to start using my phone normally, there was a pop up that said something like: SD card malfunctioned, reformat now.
when i clicked "yes" for the reformat, there was some strange machine code type of gobbledygook, something that said "...failure". so i turned off the phone, pulled out the sd card drawer, carefully reseated both the SD card as well as the sim card. restarted the phone.
no to avail, neither the File Manager nor ASTRO app see any SD card now.
anyone else has issues with their SD card/card reader? 
it seems like the phone no longer sees a card inserted.
my sd card is Samsung and i just bought it from B&H, which is about as legit as it gets.

replies.text:
Have you tried another card? Just to verify its a card issue or phone/reader issue
Last time ive had a sd card go bad in a phone on me so when I had a S4. Ended up having to buy a new sd card.
Try putting your card in an adapter and putting in your computer and see if it recognizes it. If it does back everything up to your computer and try reformatting through your computer then reinstall.

This happened to me about 2 weeks into owning my S8+. At the end of it all my SD card was completely corrupted to the point I couldn't even format it to use again. Had to buy a new one and start from scratch.

Mine got dropped of by the ups man at about 6pm. Got home from work at 715 and haven't put it down yet. Its everything I had hoped it would be and more. Bluetooth LDAC with my Sony headphones is sounding awesome! Got all my apps downloaded and signed into all my apps with my fingerprint. Everything is all set. Awesome screen just like the S8, stereo speakers are awesome as well. Glad to not be using that iPhone anymore.
The Spigen ultra hybrid s with the kickstand is also on it and is feeling pretty nice in my hands.
any reason to use the sim card in the box as opposed to using my existing SIM card?

replies.text: Don't think so. I never use them
I always keep them as spares as T-Mobile tends to charge you for them sometimes. I've only ever needed to use them once. Idk how the Sim I was using went bad.
My new Sim card wasn't activated so I ended up having to swap with the old one. Probably best just to use your old one.

No, like another member stated maybe hang onto it though. I upgrade to a new phone every year and I'm pretty sure I'm on the same SIM card from my Galaxy S4 when I switched to T-Mobile and switched to Android.
I'm using the same SIM card from my Note 3 (2013)
I never understood why T-Mobile makes us pay for a new SIM every time we upgrade. I bought my T-Mobile S9+ from Samsung directly and they included a T-Mobile SIM for free.

I purchased a S9 & a S9 Plus directly from T-Mobile & the sim cards were in the boxes. I didn't pay for them. The attached pic from a T-Mobile support page shows that a retail T-Mobile phone comes with a sim. Is it different using JOD?

Dunno. Every time I've bought a phone through them, they tack on $25 or something for a SIM card. I actually had a S9+ in my T-Mobile cart alongside the Samsung cart and they had a charge for the SIM on there.
Well that's certainly strange... & unfair.  That could really add up if you were a long time customer. I'm glad you were able to get your S9+ from Samsung. That's 25.00 you can use for accessories.
When you got it through Samsung, did you pay a down payment? The down payment is half the reason I returned mine and kept my Note 8. The other half is because I still like my Note 8 (lol)
I got the Samsung financing and I was able to finance the balanced. Though, I expect to pay it off quickly.
Ok good - so Samsung didn't ask for a down payment the way the carrier did  Good ! It's really nice having that option to get into the phone that way, then pay off as you please.
They also applied sales tax after deducting for my trade. So it worked out to a better deal and I don't have to stick with T-Mobile for 2 years to get the full trade value back.
It is an activation fee. Plain and simple. They just decided to change the name and pretend it isn't that but .. it is.
Pretty much. But lame either way. I have a bunch of SIM cards in a drawer at home...

Yeah that is why it is an upgrade / activation fee. The other carriers call them upgrade fees now which do somewhat line up more with the actual fee charge since they do only charge it when upgrading. T-Mobile calling it a SIM fee is odd since most customers will be like you -- "Why can't I use my old SIM?" .. The answer is you can but mine as well use the new one they force you to buy.
I have always been successful in having that fee waived by a manager and/or customer care because I tell them I have a stack of SIM cards to use instead of being wasteful and buying another.

Yeah .. I can get the upgrade fee waived if I complain enough to a manager at Verizon as well. It's still just dumb for T-Mobile to change the name as if the fee isn't an upgrade or activation fee. They are trying to make it be something it isn't.
Was TMobile using UICC type SIM in 2013? I believe you need UICC for LTE to work properly. Maybe double check.

thread.text: Wondered why no protection was installed. Neither was installed for me. Installed Lookout since i assumed that was what they still use.
I usually delete those apps. Less bloat the better

Reading thru these posts I must say I'm surprised how many of you guys use the "smart switch" to transfer from a previous phone. I figured we were mainly all techies here and knew a fresh install is much more recommended especially when switching to a different phone model.

replies.text: As far as I can tell, smart switch just queues up the apps to be installed, matches the settings on from your old phone and transfers data to the new phone. I don't think it's functionally different than installing the apps yourself, changing all the settings and moving files to the new phone...

I always do a fresh install, most of my data, photos and music are in the cloud so it's not a big deal for me to do a fresh install. Just have to install the apps and if you are using launcher like Nova you can just back up the home screen layout and import it after the fresh install if you don't want to set up the home screen again.

thread.text:
My S7 had a setting where calendar notifications could have a separate notification tone. In my case this was a segment of a music file in the SD card.

Hi - I got my new s9 yesterday. Today I set up the email client. Can't use SSL, but that was the same on my old phone. 
I also have a client with the same email on my computer. The emails loaded onto my phone, and I went and deleted them to keep things clean on the phone. Then I went to my computer email and all of the emails were gone because they were deleted from the server when I deleted them on the phone. 
I assumed what was on my computer would have stayed, but it didn't. I had to go back to the phone and move the deleted mails back out to the inbox, so even mail I'd deleted on the computer ended up back in the inbox. I just preordered a Lilac Purple S9 from Verizon. 
I had been debating whether to order from Verizon, Samsung, or Best Buy. What I found out by going thru the ordering process for each online was that all three options required you to use the 24 month payment plan in order to trade in a phone and get the discount. 
So for me Verizon was $599.99 (with a $200 trade in), Samsung was$649.99 (with a $150 trade in) and Best Buy was $691.92 with the $100 off for March 2 orders only. 
With Best Buy I didn't see how you could apply a trade in gift card that would go towards to cost of the phone since you had to accept the 24 month plan or else pay the full price which was $792. If I had bought it outright from BB then the cost would have been $642 IF I could apply the gift card at the time of purchase. And that is iffy. Some have said yes you can and others have said no. At any rate that still came out to $50 more for me over Verizon.
You do have to pay for sales tax for the full price and a $30 activation fee.

Nope. Samsung updates their unlocked devices last the majority of the time. Carrier versions take priority for them. And I didn't trade anything in. Best Buy full price for it on yesterday was 912 and then they gave me 100 off for getting it yesterday so total came out to 812 and it's split over 24 months.
hmmmm i remember my s8 plus getting an update last on verizon last year
It wasn't after the unlocked. Look it up anywhere, unlocked models in the US get updates last the majority of the time.

Unless you're actively using the "bloat", the device will be the exact same speed. They can easily be disabled on the Verizon version. Only Pro to the unlocked version is that you can easily switch carriers. However, for the time being, Verizon phones still come unlocked so not much of a benefit for people who buy the Verizon version. Mostly just cons to getting the unlocked except for the price. However, Best Buy eliminated the price difference as well. Now when Verizon starts locking the phones down in the name of "theft deterrent" then there will be a benefit to the unlocked. I hope one day Samsung starts pushing updates to the unlocked devices more quickly. That would be awesome.

I am holding out until Verizon offers S9+ with 128GB internal storage. No idea why they are only taking orders for 64GB versions. The UK launched with both. SD card storage is nice but tedious to move apps to SD, they run more slowly on SD, and system OS updates move apps back to internal memory undoing all the work to move them there. So the only solution for me is 128GB internal memory. Surprised more people aren't complaining about this.

replies.text: You will likely be waiting forever. Probably not gonna happen.
Is this your speculation or do you have specific knowledge?

Speculation based on the past. I'm not an insider or anything. I would bet money though that you'll never see a 128gb Verizon version. If anything you might see an unlocked 128gb, but if that were the case it probably would have been available from the jump.

I know you mentioned you were surprised that you hadn't seen more complaints about that. There's a reason why people aren't complaining. People don't care. I would consider myself a power user, but even I don't have 64gb worth of apps, and everything else can be stored on an SD card. 64gb with expandable storage is probably enough for 99.5% of their user base if not more than that. You'll notice that other than iPhones and the Pixel (which doesn't have expandable storage), most carriers don't seem to offer more than one storage sku of phones. There's a reason for that. The higher storage Skus don't sell. If you don't have people who visit forums complaining though, I can just about guarantee you that the general consumer couldn't care less.

title: Samsung Galaxy S9+ or Pixel 2 XL?

thread.text: Any suggestions?

replies.text: Hard to really suggest since we know nothing about the S9. Anything "known" is just rumors.

No. We know the S9 will be using the next gen Snapdragons and Exynos. That is fact.
As for the OP. Depends. Have you used a Samsung before? What phone are you coming from? Does it need to be now? Are you fine with Samsung releasing the security patches in a not consistent manner (ranging from monthly to up to 2mos late in some cases for carriers) and getting the OS update up to 6mos late?
Aside from the fact that from a performance standpoint the S9 is better than the Pixel 2 (The Exynos at least. The SD 845 is already better than the SD 835 in the Pixel and the Exynos 9's benchmarks have it at 2x faster than the SD 845 for single core), most of the other items for consideration are software.
Lol you have been around long enough to know exactly what I meant ... But if you want to split hairs .. BY all means go ahead ^_^.

There's a good article on AC that breaks down why benchmarks are getting less and less important each year. It's a given that most new flagships will be technically superior than the previous model. But when it comes to practical usage, the S9 and S8 models will be just as fast and fluid to use as the last three models of iPhone. Phones are fast, and the specs generally don't matter to most people when we talk about SoCs.

thread.text:
Depends on when you want a new phone, now or months from now.
If you can wait, I'd see what the S9+ has to offer.

I was deciding between those two as well. I went with the Pixel 2 XL after the rumored price increase of the S9 and S9+. I'm just not going to spend a grand or more on a phone in 2018. That said, I'm really happy with the Pixel. To me, the screen is not as bad as folks make it out to be. Blue shift, yes a bit, but it is only noticeable on a light background and I don't usually hold my phone at an angle to use it anyway.
It's what You want that really matters in the end. Imagine an 8.1 software update out of the box! I've had the phone 3 days and already have as many software updates as my S7 Edge got in 2 yrs, not counting security patches.
I do miss the wireless charging but I can live without. I don't know if that helps you, but that's my two cents! 😉
Thanks Speedtrap63. I am still on the fense and are hoping to get some hint next week. it seems to be a SW vs HW paradigm with pricing in the mix.
How about both? Why not?

Want added touchwiz skin and apps that duplicate stock Android? That will be the biggest difference. The Pixel is very fluid and gets updates first and monthly security patches. This camera at the moment is the top, but that could change with the S9. Also you'll get wireless charging and likely an SD card. So really it boils down on a checklist of wants. I don't think you can go wrong with either decision.

I used to be all-in on Samsung, but despite the amazing hardware, the software doesn't get updated as often as I'd like it to be. I've been super happy with the Pixel 2 XL. My ex uses an S7 Active and she was just amazed at how well the pictures turned out on the P2XL.

No such thing anymore as one phone being "better" than another. So like always, only you know what you want in a smartphone. This varies from individual to individual. So never go by why someone else bought this or that. Pick whichever phone bet fits your needs. So don't get too caught up with all the what's better, lg v30, iPhone x, oneplus5T, Note 8 pixel xl 2 etc.. talk and get whatever you think is best for you.

I am using a S7E with Exynos. I do wish to have faster software updates, but at the same time I really like Samsung's hardware: screen, design, 3.5mm jack, wireless charging, etc.
I do notice S7E to stutter a bit after 1.5 years... didn't bother me much but definitely will enjoy lag free experience more. Redundant apps don't bother me. S9+ will have more than enough flash memory plus an SD extension
The only hardware Pixel 2 XL has on S9+ is probably the dual speaker.
Decisions decisions

replies.text: Some if not a lot of that stuttering can be attributed to the battery's age. As the battery ages, it may not be able to provide all the energy the phone needs to run optimally. That's actually the reason why Apple throttles the CPU as the battery ages, to prevent stutters.
Are you serious chanchan05?

Serious about what? Yes, that's basic battery tech. And yes, I am just repeating what Apple said as their reason. Batteries over time and usage deteriorates. Not only are they not able to hold as much charge as before, but in some cases they are not able to provide as much current.

Apple was publicly embarrassed when it was revealed new OS releases intentionally throttle older devices. So they had to say something. Whether what they said was true or not is still up for debate.
Assuming what was said is true, can you say for certain that the Qualcomm and Samsung SOCs use the same power management strategies as Apple's hardware?
It seems like you're making a lot of logical leaps here.

Ah. You're misunderstanding. I am not saying they're throttling. I am saying that batteries are known to have detetiorate over time. It is also known that one of the symptoms of battery deterioration is decreased current from time to time. Apple throttled their phones to avoid the stuttering. Samsung does not throttle, so stuttering on an older battery should be expected.

Got it.
I wasn't aware lower current could cause stuttering. While it does make some sort of logical sense, does this actually happen? Is the evidence that proves this happens hard or anecdotal?

http://www.batteryeducation.com/2006...y_degrada.htmlhttps://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4526891/https://www.powerstream.com/internal-resistance.htm
Basically, it's a known fact that aging components increase the impedance on the internals of a battery. Increased impedance/resistance leads to inefficient energy flow.

I just skimmed these articles but all three seemed to provide information about expected service life of Li-On batteries. Nothing surprising or new here...
What I was wondering about was whether or not a degraded battery affected SoC performance...which is what you contend. I didn't know this was a thing and didn't see anything about this particular issue in any of the links your provided, unless I missed something.
My experience is that battery condition does not affect a phone's performance. This is based on a whopping sample size of 2. My Nexus 6P was a lag-fest even after a battery replacement. My S3 was perennially slow towards the end of its useful lifespan and that was with 2 new batteries (I miss user-replaceable batteries).

Don't forget the Pixel camera is outstanding!
That said from your list of likes above sounds like you've made your decision. I don't think you can make a bad choice, but it seems like the S9+ might be best for you.
The Pixel 2 has a dedicated SOC for the camera
I thought the Visual Core was technically a co-processor that the actual SoC could hand off HDR post-processing tasks to and that the camera itself is still running on the Snapdragon 835
That's still qualifies for the camera

thread.text:
The S8 had a decent discount around Thanksgiving, so I finally picked it up. Ended up returning it to get the Pixel 2 and couldn't be happier. The only thing I liked more on the S8 was the display; Samsung obviously makes some of the best displays at all sizes. That being said, the curved edges were annoying and led to a lot of accidental touch input. Also was not a fan of the taller ratio. The software and UI drove me crazy (had been using Motorola the last few years, so used to more stock software.) Couldn't stand all the extra options, all the duplicate apps, the separate logins for Samsung, etc. The fingerprint sensor location was also annoying and not consistent for me; it was always prompting me to cover it completely.
I went with the Pixel 2 for the faster updates, closer to stock Android, and the amazing camera (although I do wish it had some of the manual features Samsung includes.) The FPS is in a better spot and hasn't given me any issues. The speakers are very loud and clear. The display is more than good enough for me. I have the non-XL version so the bezels are obviously not ideal, but that's far from a deal breaker (also not an issue on the 2 XL.) I think both phones have underwhelming battery for my usage and expectations (again, probably better on the 2 XL or S9+)
Other than the S9 having the FPS in a better spot and an upgraded the camera, I feel like I would still have many of the same gripes as I had with the S8. I love the look and feel of my Pixel 2 and wouldn't consider getting the S9 over it, even if it were the same price. 
Just my two cents; good luck whatever you decide! They are both amazing devices.

I do like Samsung's hardware better.... but getting latest OS upgrade as soon as it comes out for a few year is such a pro for going with Pixel... Pixel 3 backed by HTC developers could be the best of both worlds.

I have had the SG7, SG8+, and Note8. Now have a Pixel 2 (smaller size), and I’m impressed with how well the Pixel works. Coupled with the extreme lag of updates by Samsung, and I won’t get another one any time soon. I like the Samsung hardware to be honest, but it is less snappy than Pixel and security updates (and especially major updates) are always lagging.

The only issue with going Pixel.... Is that you won't be very excited when the "next new phone" comes out.
I have a Pixel XL, got it day 2. 
It runs SO SMOOTHLY, I never considered a Pixel2 XL and don't think I will be considering a Pixel3 XL.
I have never had, never seen, a phone that runs this smooth for this amount of time. Sure a new phone runs great for 6 months. Then the lag starts, then you factory reset, then a few months later the lag comes back.
The Pixel simply does not have lag.... Ever.
In the entire time I have had this phone I have only turned it off a handful of times, and then it was when the wife was wanting my attention, not because the phone needed it.
Depends on what you want in a phone. But if you want it to work as good on day xxx as it did on day 1... PIXEL

I have a P2XL, on my 3rd one d/t display issues. The one I have now is good. I like the updates and stock Android but I'm gonna try the S9+. I'm going to keep the phone I like. I'm thinking I'll like the display on the Samsung. Rooting/modding used to be an issue for me but the firmware on phones has become so complex it's hard to improve on the stock config.

Still on the fence... reluctant to get S9+. Pixel 2 XL's screen is a bit turn-off though... weird, usually I pull trigger pretty fast. Maybe the phones nowadays are just this good... even my S7E isn't that bad after almost 2 years.
The other day my phone got so greasy with finger prints, I just went to washroom and used the soap to wash it clean, without thinking too much about it

I would probably keep a Pixel or 2XL if they offered more features. But like everyone says. You really buy a Pixel for updates and being more fluid. Me personally would rather have wireless charging,ip68,sd expansion and Samsung Pay. If the next Pixel has ip 68 and wireless charging I would seriously think about getting and keeping one. I guess time will tell

title: Can Google Calendar app have separate notification sound?

thread.text:
I've been trying to figure out how to give the Google Calendar app that I'm using on the S9 a different notification sound than the one that text messages use. Not seeing how to do that.
So I have these questions:
- Is there a way to allow the Google Calendar app to have a distinct notification sound?
- If I use the Samsung Calendar app, does that allow me to have a distint calendar notification sound?
- Can I sync the Samsung Calendar app with my Google calendars?
Thanks!

replies.text: The default Samsung one does. Open the app. Click the top where the three dots are. Go to settings and then notifications. Then general sound notifications and change the sound you want.

thread.text:
For Google Calendar, open the app, tap Menu>Settings>General>Calendar Notifications>Sound, and you can specify a tone for all Calendar notifications there.
Syncing your Samsung Calendar events with Google Calendar depends on what account your Samsung Calendar events are entered into. If it's the local Phone account or the Samsung account, those won't sync with Google Calendar -- you'd have to look for an Export option and export those events to an .ics file, then import them to your Google Calendar: https://support.google.com/calendar/answer/37118?hl=en

replies.text: Thanks, perfect. Couldn't have buried it deeper if they tried *smile*.

Got to say that overall I love this phone.

title: SD Card on 9+ not writing pics

thread.text:
My s9+ wont write pics to the Samsung EVO 128gb sd. A single photo will sometimes show in the preview circle but when clicked shows a grey page in Gallery. If I use burst then the first pic will sometimes show in gallery but the phone will lock up and go dead for ten or fifteen seconds when I try it again. I switched to store pics on phone and it works perfectly.
I mounted and unmounted the card and when that did not correct problem I reformated it in the s9+ and the same situation occurs. The phone has been restarted after each step.
I should add that prior to reformatting the card, the previous photos on the card were in the gallery and the phone had no problem showing them. The card was previously in my s8+

Welcome to Android Central! The SD card could be corrupt, defective, or counterfeit. Install SD Insight to see if the card is genuine or counterfeit. Counterfeit cards are programmed to report more storage than they actually have, and if you try saving more than the card can actually hold, then files can start getting corrupt. (Be aware that SD Insight might not work on all Nougat devices.)
If it's a valid card, then go to Settings>Storage, Unmount the card, remove it, and insert it into your computer. Can the computer read these files? Backup as much as you can right now, then run chkdsk to look for bad sectors: http://forums.androidcentral.com/amb...d-sd-card.html

title: Notifications not waking up lock screen?

thread.text:
Have a new Samsung S9, and when I get a notification like for a text message, or for two-factor authentication confirmation from an app, etc., the lock screen doesn't wake up. So I hear the notification sound, and when I open the phone the notification is waiting on the lock screen.
Been through settings, and I must have missed something...are there some particular settings that affect this? The apps themselves are set to allow notification on the lock screen, and that part works. I've gone to "Lock Screen and Security" in settings, and selected the apps that I want notifications from to show on the lock screen, and they do show on the lock screen.
But I haven't seen a setting for "wake up the lock screen for notifications", I suspect that's somewhere that I haven't found yet? Or something related to that that I'm not seeing?
Thanks for your help!

I did find a simple app that I used to use in my library, called "Screen Notifications". It works, but I'd much rather have a native way of doing this, without having to use an app. There must be one, this seems like an obvious thing to want to do, at least to me *smile*.

replies.text: I second this app. I use this on all my phones that don't have screen wake for notifications as a system setting. It

thread.text:
That's because notifications aren't meant to wake the screen up in Samsung's implementation (and for people like me, that's awesome). You have an LED for that. Ad AOD. 
That being said, it will depend on the app if its notifications can wake the screen up. For instance, Samsung's messaging app and others like Textra will offer the option to do in the settings. Other than that, only phone calls and Emergency alerts will do so by default.

replies.text: With the Samsung messaging is that a s9 think because o have a note 8 and I don't see that in the settings for it to not wake up the screen when I get a text . But when I use Google messenger it does not wake it.

Not sure if the setting is there or not as I stopped using stock messaging apps PRECISELY because they wake up the screen for texts, so I switched to Textra and never looked back. 
Like I said, it's app dependent now. If Google's doesn't have the option either, then you can try a different app that does.

thread.text:
The notification light is redundant relative to the notification sound, and doesn't allow me to read the second-factor auth code in a text message. For that, I need to go to the text message. Seems like a lot of work to get a six digit code *smile*. Anyways, I have a work-around for the moment, if that's the way that Samsung wants to be. I also have a couple of apps that I want to wake the lock screen, LastPass authenticator, and two-factor notifications from gmail via the Google app. Makes it easier to get to the "Allow" and "Deny" choices quickly, since the allow choice is in the notification.
I'd be happy if waking up the lock screen were the default, but could be turned off if desired by those that don't want it. Or vice-versa. As it is, I have to chase down an app that'll do it, and have that overhead on my phone.
So it goes.

thread.text: I have more wired and Bluetooth headphones than I care to admit! They are all good for different uses.I travel a lot, so noise cancellation is key. Unfortunately last week, I accidentally packed my over the ear Bose in my checked bags. I had a long day and night of traveling ahead of me,and I had to have something. I ended up in front of one of those Best Buy electronic vending type machines in the airport. I was looking for a pair of Bluetooth headphones to get me through. But something different caught my eye, and it was a wired Bose headphone, that was stated how great the ratings were, especially audiophiles that travel often. So, I bought them, hoping for the best.I'm so glad I did, because they're absolutely amazing, and the best sound in any headphone I've ever had. It has a credit card thin, lithium noise cancelling battery, with an approximate 15 hr battery time. If that isn't enough, you may lose noise cancelling, but you can still listen to your music. I feel like I'm listening to my favorite music for the very first time. I never thought I would pay that much for non Bluetooth, but I am so glad I took a chance! Best sound ever. I hope Samsung continues to keep the headphone jack, and I will always make sure my new Bose headphones are in my carry on everywhere I go from here on!

I think though that I am starting to realize the problem is more on the type of headphone rather than the headphone itself. The S7 headphones were of an earbud type, as opposed to the S8/S9 headphones which are an earplug type. The difference in acoustics would account for the difference in tuning. Since the S7 headphones let in ambient noise, it's tuned differently. On earolug types, you need to acquire a good ear seal before you start hearing the low end. So if your ears are rather large, the default installed buds may be too small and thus not creating a seal, ruining the acoustics of the headphone.

You don't have to work hard. You just need to get the right tips. There are 2 additional pairs of tips included in the package. They are not replacement tips. They are different sized tips so you choose the one that fits you best. ALL earplug type earbuds have that. Some even give 4 different sizes in the package. There are even aftermarket memory foam tips that provide even better seal and creates better acoustics. It's simply the nature of the earplug design.
Personally I prefer the earplug design over the earbuds.

thread.text:
For anybody saying that these sound thin or inferior to any other stock buds that any manufacturer is providing, I have to guess that you didn't yet find the "sound quality and effects" subsection at the bottom of the page under "sounds and vibrations," which I think is a stupid place to put such a premium set of features. At the top is the Dolby Atmos option, which I haven't tested yet because that is for movies, etc. You may have even heard the process in some better theaters who may have 1 screen dedicated for it. I saw the last two of the recent Planet of the Apes films in Dolby Atmos. Incredibly clean.
But as far as the buds, I just tested these in the "real world" setting of a coffee house with 22 people in it for their morning coffee and chat. As far as blocking out noise, it isn't 100%, but I don't know of any that are. But I will say that I started when the place was basically empty and it wasn't until I took them off an hour later that I was shocked by how loud the place had gotten. That increase in ambient volume in the Cafe was basically unnoticeable with the AKGs in.
As far as the music, this was a test for myself, but I sat and first played my favorite speaker test track; Oliver Nelson's Stolen Moments. I first went to the stock genre equalizer presets and the Jazz setting was noticeably more appropriate than the others. Historically, these types of presets have always felt more random or approximated by the software. But not on this. So I left the manual equalizer controls untouched, even though there were a couple of tweaks that I was feeling compelled to change. But the treatments below that are where the real satisfaction comes. For the lushness of this track, I had room to move by flipping on the UHQ upscaler without it getting tinny. And then I added Tube Amp Pro for warmth. I am sure that on a lesser device, these options would have simply canceled each other out and sounded relatively the same as having them both off. But not here. They are performing very distinct functions.
The next track was the RVG series' Lee Morgan's - The Sidewinder (you guessed it, I listen to a lot of jazz). And on this track, with Lee's trumpet being (understandably) so far up in the mix, the only Chang that I made was taking off the UHQ.
But then I saw this thread and tested a bit more. Moved to Mercury Rev's Dark is Rising, another of my favorite speaker test songs. I moved Jazz to Rock, took off Tube Amp and added UHQ again. It was probably fine, but I couldn't control myself any longer and did very modest tweaks, bringing up the mid and bringing down the low ever so slightly. Then Mudhoney - Baby, Can You Dig The Light (Tube Amp back on). Then Handsome Family - The Woman Downstairs (not that I think that they are pop, but the Pop preset was the only change that I made to make this song transplendent). Then went to the remaster of ZZ Tops Fandango to bounce around between live and studio tracks, just to test out the "concert hall" feature. The reverb in the original mastering of this album, already adds a distinct level of depth on the live and studio tracks, which was part of the ZZ Top sound through that era of their career. I wanted to see if the added effect pushed it over the edge or not. So I moved Pop back to Rock and added "concert hall" to this already live track; Thunderbird. With the caffeine of my xlarge coffee refill coursing through me, it was hard to contain myself as this was only the second time in my life that I thought that this feature ever sounded right. The first being Bob Marley's Uprising on vinyl in the early 90s through a pair of Klipschorns. I still get chills thinking abould the first song played through these already seasoned speakers; Coming In From the Cold. (note: my current regular buds are also from Klipsch, so the AKGs have had a lot to stand up to)
I then moved on to my two favorite songs on this album; Nasty Dogs & Funky Kings and Blue Jeans Blues. NDAFK sounded great with concert hall and all other settings the same, but I also played the first minute or so minus concert hall and that would be my preference. And lastly, for Blue Jean Blues, I put concert hall back on and the opening guitar sounded cool, almost haunting. But as soon as the vocals kicked in, it was too animated sounding to continue with concert hall, but the song was pristine without it.
Of course, I won't be doing this kind of switching around once I find a more universal, personal sweet spot in the settings. In fact, there is even a function at the very bottom that seems to figure that out for you, as well. Maybe I will try it at some point. But if anybody is feeling let down by these ear buds, make sure that you you have given them a fair chance with how they were intended to be used with the S9.
Peace, 
Ras

title: Windows phone users (Lumia 950 XL or others) - Did you migrate to a S9/S9+?

thread.text:
I wanted to start a thread to see if there were any Windows phone users out there that migrated off one and to a new S9 or S9+.
I am on the 3rd day using a S9 plus device (SM-G965U1), coming from my 950 XL. I am not sure if my Lumia will lay unused now or what will happen. I am slowly able to adapt in how use the S9+ in its slight differences and interstingly its similarities. I have used Samsung off and on since the S6 Edge Plus but never daily as my main mobile device needed. I was using Windows phones though primariy for the last 3 years or so...I had to start moving off my Lumia 950 XL due to several factors. Some of which are listed below. Phone call stability and sms/mms for me while on T-Mobile became finicky. Battery life is normally good but web browsing was always a reason to think otherwise, chewing through the battery while web pages are open. The UX/UI of Windows 10 mobile though is so unique natural and simplistic to me that I have attempted to make any aspect of the S9+ mimic it. Yet it will never match that which I grew to appreaciate. Despite this it is just Android and like we know "different strokes for different folks". 
Anyway chime in too if you'd like.
I am impressed by the S9 Plus. Simply put, it for me could and just might replace my 950 XL. I guess I am a bit undecided, but am approaching that threshold of breaking the indecisiveness soon.
This device checks a lot of boxes for almost any user...
The screen is more than adequate and can be calibrated in many ways - Check
The Sound quality off the device and 3.5mm jack are impressive - Check
The build quality is excellent - Check
Cellular/MMS/SMS work well for me (T-mobile) with no issues - Check
Software manageability and tweaking from my perspective is great, with lots of features baked in or able to be added through the Android ecosystem - Check
Microsoft Services work great on it (Groove, Edge, Exchange etc.) - Check
The camera is Samsung's best to date on a mobile phone, for me I have no real complaints with it. It works and takes great shots for my type of usage. The Lumia 950 XL is a stellar camera phone hands down, but I feel comfortable enough with the S9 Plus so... - Check
Battery life is really good on it. I have found that with the right configuration or enough services/apps disabled that you are not using, it can be even better. - Check
Has anyone needed to move from a Windows phone/Windows 10 Mobile and chose the S9 or S9 plus? Share your thoughts if you would like.
I made the switch from Windows to Android, though not the s9. It was difficult at first but now, I'm enjoying every bit of it

Making a permanent switch from W10m to Android is getting easier than ever now features on the Lumia are getting more dated and as support for apps and the OS gets more diluted everyday. Microsofts growing involvement on Android is a big help too and things like Microsoft Launcher and Edge browser etc make it feel a lot less alien

I have also gone into safe mode and it still doesnt work
Restarted the phone several times
Is there anything i can do to fix this?
