title: The S9+ DXO score is misleading

thread.text:
Wait, I'm not here to bash. I'm only here to point out that an aggregate score is not necessarily indicative of performance WHERE IT MATTERS.
Case in point, the individual category scores from the S9+ compared to the Pixel 2. Zoom and bokeh are two primary reasons why the aggregate score is better on the S9+ (noise being the third, but that wouldn't make up the difference if you remove zoom and bokeh), even though the Pixel 2 probably does better in every other situation and does score higher in all other categories (again, aside from noise).
What I wouldn't mind is having a discussion about why DXO inherently handicaps phones that only have one rear camera versus two. It seems a bit.....disingenuous? I think I would like to see them give scores that don't include those categories, and then scores that do. I'd even be willing to say that leaving bokeh makes some sense since at least one company with a single rear camera makes claims to be able to do bokeh just fine (but doesn't quite match phones with two rear cameras).https://twitter.com/mkbhd/status/969...703849984?s=21 (shared his tweet for the reply with the individual category scores next to each other)

replies.text:
I don't follow the logic here. I don't think it is disingenuous at all. If they removed the categories, they would not be comparing the full capabilities of the cameras. The iphone 8+ has a better camera than the iphone 8 and the scores reflect. If someone is considering both phones, it is helpful to know how they compare. 
It doesn't make sense to say that categories should only be considered if the manufacturer makes a claim they are good at that category. So if a company said their camera is not good at focusing, are you saying DXO's review should not consider focusing ability for that camera, so they can get a more competitive score??
"WHERE IT MATTERS" depends on what kind of pictures you take. If you take pictures of people, then zoom and bokeh are very important. If you you take landscapes, those things are not important. Anyone can look at the individual category scores and decide what matters to them.

This is something that I've been suspecting for a while since DxO released their new scoring system.
It just seems to favor devices that use a very specific approach to dual cameras, specifically those used for enhanced zoom capabilities. It just seems to put phones with different dual camera approaches or ones with single cameras at a disadvantage.What he's saying is that the overall aggregate score is misleading. The overall score for the S9 is 99, with the photo score being 104. However, if you actually read the scores awarded in each individual metric, the main reason the S9 scored much higher was the secondary camera on the S9+, meaning that it does much better than the P2 in the zoom category. This is a major contributor to why the S9+ scored more. 
In fact, when it comes to the core photography performance (exposure/contrast, autofocus, texture, color), the Pixel wins, with the exception of noise, of which the S9's multi-frame processing seems to do a good job of clearing.
This is a perfect example of why aggregate scores shouldn't be treated as a sole measure of overall camera performance. When you first see it, you would think the S9 has finally beaten the Pixel 2 but when you see it further, you only realize that it beat it mostly in one category that the scoring system favors and that in most other areas, it isn't better than the P2.

One of the main objectives of the new scoring system was to take into consideration manufacturers' efforts to improve zoom and bokeh. So I would expect phones that use dual cameras to enhance zoom to show better scores, all else held equal. If they didn't do that the iphone 8 would have the same score as the iphone 8+, which would be an absurd result.
I don't see evidence they are favoring an specific implementation approach, just the result. Evidence to the contrary is the fact that before the Galaxy S9+, the Pixel 2 was the highest rated camera of all, beating all of the cameras with dual lens setups.
It is inevitable when you aggregate a number to summarize a review like this, it will work better for some users than others. 
DXO is transparent and discusses their methodology in detail. They say in their methodology they "weigh the various results in a way that most closely matches their importance in real-world applications as judged by mainstream users" but they add "However, every user is different, and each has differing priorities. For that reason, we encourage anyone reading our reviews to dig in past the Overall score into the sub-scores and written analysis."

Here's the thing.
People are dumb. They just see the aggregate score and think the S9+ is better than the Pixel 2
Even though the S9+ is better than it in a few areas while the Pixel 2 is better in other areas.
I'm sure DxO wants to be as fair and transparent as possible. But I still can't shake the feeling that this scoring methodology puts a lot of phones with different dual camera implementations or single camera devices at a small disadvantage unless they can make up for the deficiency with superb post processing like the Pixel 2. If a phone has a dual camera implementation that enhances zoom, it's probably going to score more in that area than those that use it differently or only has one sensor. Which is fine but when it pushes a phone to an overall score that edges a phone that does better in the core essentials, it's a bit icky. 
I understand why they did it. I just think that people are going to take the whole aggregate scoring thing the wrong way. 
It's also a reminder that people need to read more into why a score is given.

"WHERE IT MATTERS" - Zoom and bokeh only matter in specific situations. The things that the Pixel 2 score higher in matter all the time, with every single image.
Having scores on the S9 would be very useful, but they didn't do that. As you stated, they scored both iPhones, which makes it easy to see just how much they weight zoom and bokeh. I hope they rate the S9 too at some point in the near future.

This....
This is the heart of the matter... DXO has been weighting zoom and portrait modes far too heavy since they were first introduced. They are both additional features designed to augment pictures, and are only used in certain circumstances. Things like exposure, focus, color, contrast, noise, detail and clarity, those are CORE features of a camera and apply to every picture taken.
So where people have issues here is that when it comes to an aggregate score, those secondary features seem to be weighted more than core features that are significantly more important. Why? Well, its trendy. The two dominant phone marks have dumped a ton of effort into those two features and they are the 'in' thing. Samsung and Apple want to sell phones, and it's becoming harder to differentiate as the platform matures and there's less fruit on the vine to pick from. Zoom and portraits are sexy... they make for good marketing campaigns and draw attention.
But they don't necessarily lead to better pictures... something that appears to not be that big a priority (at least from DXO's perspective)

I'm not disagreeing with you but noise does matters in most cases no matter how bright or dark the photo is.
Especially if the S9 scored 20 points higher than the Pixel in that category.
At the most the Pixel beat the S9 by 7 points in those scores.
Just saying.

They should have weighed that more.
Zoom and bokeh shouldn't be weighed as much as stuff like noise, texture and exposure IMHO
Short version is that the Pixel 2 XL is a better camera than the S9+, but loses on the aggregate score. The logic is that the stronger camera should probably win on total score.

Funny...I don't remember Pixel owners complaining about DXOMark when they ranked Pixel 2 the highest.
Phone camera hardware & software improve from release to release. I'm sure when the next iPhone is released, these forums will be flooded with complaints about the camera rating. Same with the next Pixel, Note, etc.

replies.text:
It's not that the S9+ scored more.
It's just that the score itself can be misleading.
It would lead you to believe that the S9+ is better than the Pixel 2 overall but in actuality, it's better in zoom, noise and bokeh but not in other areas.
It's a good example that one shouldn't take an aggregate score for what it is. It's important that you examine just how they came to that score and why

Yea, every time DxOMark publishes a score, we hear this a lot - “score can be misleading” - well, they are becoming and I think have become the mainstream media for rating smartphone cameras. 
I wish everyone understood to dig deeper into individual scores but everyone will focus on the overall aggregate score as that is what matter at the end of the day when you talk numbers.
Hopefully DxOMark can improve the way they score things, but this is what we have today.

I just personally feel that trying to describe the performance of an entire camera system with a single set of numbers is pretty difficult, because it's an aggregate of multiple factors, some of which matter more than others.
Does the S9 have a good camera? Yes, maybe even great. Is DxO's scoring for individual metrics flawed? No, because I think it's accurate to what the camera performs.
But is the aggregate score a bit misleading at first? IMO, yeah, especially when they are getting heaps of mainstream attention.

thread.text: Here's a comparison by feature:

I agree that zoom and bokeh shouldn't be weighed as much as stuff like noise, texture and exposure. But I don't know that it wasn't because DXO doesn't publish the weighting.
However, the S9+'s total score for exposure, texture, noise, and color is higher than the Pixel's total score for those same elements, 318, vs 313. Not a big difference for sure. Had they weighted noise more (which I agree with since noise is typically the major weakness of mobile phone cameras), the S9+ have won by a bigger margin.
That said, I don't know if the S9+ has a better camera than the Pixel, I've only seen a few samples from the S9+, not enough to form an opinion.
After seeing a few of the mainstream reviews it seems the consensus is that, generally speaking, the Pixel 2 wins. Low light being one exception.

replies.text: I think it would be difficult for you to find somebody that knows what they're talking about that's going to disagree with that.
But low light counts

Sure it does. But it's also situational. And isn't a sub-category in the dXo score. My point is that real-world use does not line up with the dXo score.
Additional point: dXo is a synthetic benchmark and the results will not always mirror the real-world experience. (so treat it like any other benchmark)

It does, and while the S9 does improve there... It still lacks the dynamic range of the Pixel. Blown out signs in nighttime shots in the city... Or windows in the background when taking pictures inside... Brighter isn't always better. Google's phones going back to the 6P handle these so much better than anything else in the market... and without garish processing artifacts or heavy handed noise reduction.
So seeing these messed up highlights or overly sterlized shots ruin the pictures for me... I want cameras to take pictures the way I see things with my own eyes and the only phones out there that come close come from Google.

Well if you think the Pixel beats the S9+ in every area I don't agree. I've already seen samples and the S9+ has just as nice pictures in certain situations. Why is everybody so in an uproar over the S9+? I don't understand. I didn't rate the S9+ the top score in the smartphone cameras DXO Mark did. So what. I really don't think you are going to get the best picture with the same phone every time. Between all the top of the line smartphone cameras available no 1 camera is the best at everything

I never said that... And there are some situations where the S9 does appear to do better. I'm only saying that I've seen shots where Samsung appears at times to make some odd processing choices that companies like LG make... Such as an apparent aversion to keeping people's faces the way they look rather than some stylized version akin to the airbrushing of old.
Both take excellent pictures, albeit using different approaches. 
Though, one thing that seems lacking in the tests I've seen are shots of people in those nighttime and lower light situations. I had a V30 for a few weeks and taking shots of inanimate objects it was great... But put a person in the shot and the results were horrid... Maybe it's a thing in South Korea, but both LG and Samsung have always done very bad things to faces in those situations.
There is no better way to give a phone a death sentence than to give it to my wife and have it take mushy, overcooked pics of my kids. S7, G6, V30, Note 7 (yep, had that long enough to get a hurumph)... All failed here. S9? I need to see it in action.

thread.text: What people don't understand is there is no 1 best camera.

replies.text: Of course there isn't, but there are definitely cameras that in no way could be considered the best at anything. What this thread, and others, indicate is that, in general, dxo's scoring, at a macro level, without consulting the subscores, doesn't agree with real world results. The speculation is that this is due to undue weighting on some aspects that don't impact most photos and/or not enough weighting on the most important aspects of mobile photography.

title: Reverse SmartSwich homescreen layout and icons

thread.text: i just got the s9+. I used smarswitch from the s8 but by mistake also switched over the homepage and icons so that it looks exactly like my old s8. Is there a way to revers smartswitch so that i can have the original s9+ homescreen with the more modern icons.

you should first check to see what launcher you're using. if it's already Samsung Experience Home, then try clearing the app data.
Settings>Apps
click the 3 dots at the top right and select Show System Apps
look for Samsung Experience Home
click Storage
Clear Data
this will reset all of the Samsung Experience Home Launcher settings.

FYI
You can combine ebates + unidays discounts. 
Here is what I did via my desktop using chrome
1) login to myunidays account
2) search/activate Samsung discount (unidays will redirect you to Samsung.com)
3) log in to Samsung.com account (you should see the unidays price if you go to the preorder page, but you don’t have to do so at this time)
Do not close any browsers/tabs
4) open a new tab on your existing browser and go to ebates and login to ebates. 
5) search/follow the Samsung discount on ebates (ebates will redirect you to Samsung.com. “Noticed you still logged in to unidays and samsung”). Now you can follow the preorder page on Samsung.com and select your new toy and trade-in (if any).
I got over $40 discount on unidays and $65.97 cb on ebates. I selected the unlocked s9+ and trade in my S7. 
So, discounts+trade in value/credit came out to a little over $400 in saving for me. 
Happy shopping and enjoy your new toy.

replies.text: premium care is just Samsungs version of asurion or apple care. you can cancel it at anytime, although if you do, you are booted from the upgrade program. it's the same price as asurion(at least on att). more pricey then apple care but you get 3 claims a year at $99 per, plus onsite repair. so Forbes is being a little skeezy with the spin here. my only concern (which they don't mention in the article) is the trade in credit. it states you get UP TO %50 of your purchase price back as credit when you trade in after 12 months, but since I am only financing around $600 after my current trade in, does that mean they will only credit $300 (vs half of $915 which would be $457.50)? doesn't really matter to me, as I'll be paying off the phone by then, but those planning on paying the minimum tp qualify might want to call and get some more info from Samsung.

thread.text: I too got a FedEx notification that I will get mine tomorrow. It stated that a signature is required...
How did you request Fedex to upgrade/change from 2nd day shipping to expedited shipping?

Ordered 15 minutes after preorder started. Still no updates :/
No charge on credit card either. Do you guys see any charge ?

replies.text:
try this:
1) Create/login to fedex.com
2) After logged in, Click "Tracking" on the top of the page and select "ALL TRACKING SERVICES" - that will open up a new Tracking page
3) Click on the tab "Track by Reference"
4) In the box/field where it said "Enter up to 30 FedEx reference numbers"; enter YourOrderNumber_01 (example, my order number is ThanksSlickDeal, I'd entered: ThanksSlickDeal_01. Order number is from samsung.com)
5) Enter all the fields and click the "TRACK" button
Worked like a champ. Thanks!
Thanks for posting that! It worked for me and sure enough my two orders have been picked up and will arrive on Wed.

I'm guessing the integration with Brightpoint isn't as good as it should be. Samsung collected the orders, sent a big list of phones and addresses over to Brightpoint as a batch. Brightpoint will probably do some sort of batch update tonight or tomorrow back to samsung to notify them of the shipments. Samsung will then batch import the shipment notifications to update the site later that day or the next. By then, you will have your phone before any notification of shipment from samsung ever hits your inbox.
I've done some development for other manufacturers where we get notified of today's shipments at 5:30 the next morning and send emails out then. It is possible for the product to arrive before they even check their email the next day.

thread.text: Quick question: Do I need to pay off my trade in phone with VZ before I send it in to Samsung?

replies.text:
I did, and i think it would be good practice to do it asap. This is from the fine print of Samsung's Terms for the trade in. 
"If you send in a trade-in device and it is received within 15 days of receipt of your Qualifying Purchase but does not meet all eligibility requirements, you will be charged back the value of the trade-in credit you received minus $25. Participation in this program does not excuse you from contracts with your carrier or retailer (or any related payments or fees) for the device that was traded in. You may not participate if you lease or do not own the device you would be trading in"
If you still have a balance, you don't technically own it yet.
Thanks. That's how I was interpreting it too. Concerned they would send it back to me.
Yes, your device must be paid off.

title: Cannot get my Outlook calendar to sync with the Samsung calendar

thread.text: RESOLVED! I have tried everything. I switched from an S8 to the S9 and now my Outlook calendar items don't show in the Samsung calendar. With the help of my employer's IT department this was resolved. Deleted all previously installed Office 365/activesync accounts from all apps. Took off of wifi (office wifi signal isn't very strong) and set up through Settings/Accounts, went to Mail and followed the instructions on the screen. Now everything is synced.

Just some advice to anyone moving from IOS to Android, make sure you've set your voicemail box provisioning number correctly otherwise you'll not be able to switch VM on or off.
Had this issue myself recently after receiving my pre order SG9. Network carrier is O2 in the uk and couldn't figure out how to switch off VM, despite trying all of the correct numbers to call, i.e. 1750 (to turn vm on) and 1760 (to switch vm off).
In the end it was my provisioning number that the carrier rep had to amend for me on my tariff, apparently I had an iPhone bolt-on on my account and having switched to Android it's not compatible.
All sorted now but thought it worth offering some advice in case anyone else runs into similar issues.

title: Home screen timeout too short, how can I lengthen it

I have a Galaxy S9. After I swipe and get into the phone the home screen dims and goes off in too short of a time. I would like to lengthen the duration so it stays on longer.

Settings -----> Display ------> Screen Timeout.
You can adjust the amount of time it stays lit in there.

title: Unlocked Snapdragon S9+ AOD not turning off in pocket

thread.text:
I have a brand new S9+ ordered directly from Samsung. I have noticed that the AOD does not turn off automatically when the proximity sensor is covered. I tested this by covering it completely with black cloth on a table and waiting several minutes. I have checked my options and I have the pocket protection option on. The AOD dims, but does not turn off. The proximity sensor works normally for other things, like calls.
At this point, I'm not sure if it's a bug, specific to my model, or if it's a software issue. I really don't want to wipe just to test to see if it's an app/service interfering. I'm hoping someone else with a similar phone (read: Unlocked S9+) can confirm whether or not their AOD is going off when the proximity sensor is covered.
I had this exact issue with the S8+ last year and Samsung released an update to AOD that fixed it later. I'm hoping that's all it is. Since I literally just finished setting up my phone and logging into everything, I really don't want to wipe it, especially if it just confirms that there's a bug.
UPDATE: For anyone actually experiencing this, it was the dexterity and interaction setting under Accessibility that allows you to wave your hand over the phone to wake it up that was causing this for me.
Can I use my s5 SIM card in my s9
Nope. S5 uses micro-sim, but S9 uses nano-sim

title: Disable peek notification/ongoing battery notification on Samsung S9

thread.text:
Recently received my pre-order from Samsung, the S9. I didn't find any threads in the forum on this so I figured I would share what I learned. 
I hate the peek/heads up notification that appears on your screen while you are doing something else. I prefer to just have the notification icon in the top bar. If someone is looking at my phone they don't need to see any BBM/whatsapp/hangouts messages.
So after searching I couldn't find a way through apps or notifications. But I did find an app for "Tasker" called "Auto Notificaton". It works as a standalone app to disable the pop/up/preview notification even if the developer hasn't updated their app to support the new Android Oreo app notification features.

title: Bypassng lock screen from power button?

thread.text:
Got my S9 Plus yesterday. Is there a way to bypass the lock screen from the standby screen? Hoping there's a fix for this. When using the phone if I press the power button it takes me to the standby screen (clock, home button, etc). To get back into my phone I need to press the power button again, swipe up and unlock it (pattern, biometrics, etc.). 
I have Smart Lock enabled via Trusted Places, Trusted Devices, etc. but I'm still having to unlock my phone all the time. 
Any ideas? Thanks!

You can't bypass the lock screen with the power button but you can with the home button (hard press, needs to be enabled). If the option is active, turning the screen off with the power button will also automatically lock the phone, but if smart lock is enabled, that should be overridden. Same thing for locking the phone after a certain time since the screen times out. 
Do you have any device administrators or an exchange account maybe? Those might be blocking smart unlocks (corporate email accounts are especially picky about these)

SpookDroid, thanks, it's a new phone with no device administrators or exchange account. I figured Smart Lock would fix it but perhaps I'm misunderstanding the purpose. When I'm done using my phone I like to go to the standby screen so I press the power button to do it. I'm fine with pressing the power button again to leave the standby screen but I keep getting the unlock screen.

With smart lock that should be the case (I'm using it right now with BT headphones and even if I press the power button to go to standby it doesn't lock the phone) BUT it will show the lockscreen, which I can just swipe away, if I press the button to turn it back on. The only way I don't see the lock screen is by hard pressing the home button (again, option needs to be enabled) or by touching the FPS

Hi, 
I have two questions.
1) My S9 is converting long sms to mms, how do I make it stop?
2) The MMS won't send, it's just a spinning wheel next to the MMS. I've tried both with and without wifi.
(I'm a new Android user)

Check your carrier website and make sure that you have the proper MMS settings in your phone.
Your carrier (like many others) is converting long sms into mms so it receives as one message rather than a series of shorter sms messages.
They do the sms > mms conversion and that can't be stopped.
Sounds like your mms settings are off and that can be fixed.
Also try checking here for your settings by selecting your country/carrier from the lists: World Wide Mobile Phone Settings
Join the site to reply in this thread with more details.

Check the settings in your SMS app - a lot of them have a setting like "don't break long messages" - which means "send them by MMS". Turn that off and you'll send individual SMS messages. (Which some people have a problem receiving if they come in out of order. They get them on the screen in the order received, which can get confusing.)

The contacts are in the Outlook app (which gets them from Office 365) which is in turn synced with the stock Samsung contacts app. All the contacts are managed from Outlook and all the Outlook contacts I would expect to see appear in the stock contacts app exactly as they should (stored on phone). Exactly the same process as I used on my S7 which worked flawlessly from the word go.

I have a similar setup using S9+ and Outlook app synced with Office365 and contacts in Outlook.com plus 2017 landrover and my contacts have pulled through to the car OK. 
I was in a hurry so just synced the phone very quickly initially so I could receive calls during a journey. When I later returned to the car I waited until the phone had made it's Bluetooth link and was showing on the car display. I then went into the phone sub menu, tapped on contacts and it said it was downloading contacts. A few seconds later all my contacts from the phone were there and available to use as normal and no problems since. Not sure if that helps.

title: Buying unlocked from Samsung and using on Verizon

thread.text: If I were to purchase the S9+ unlocked from Samsung and use it on Verizon would any features not work? ie., wifi calling, HD voice, etc.

From me understanding how Verizon works and such my opinion is...
HD voice will most likely work but not WiFi calling and such. Verizon usually wants their software to have that work (versus T-Mobile and such which allow unlocked phones to use WiFi calling).
They could change since they have opened up more lately but... I think that is how it will be.

replies.text: In addition, you may also (at least in the first few weeks) not have the ability to activate a SIM with the unlocked model. You'd have to swap an already active SIM in.

thread.text:
So I have Tmobile currently and was wondering the same any downsides to buying it from Samsung unlocked directly and using TMobile?
2. If I were to switch to Verizon later in the year would that same S9+ still work just fine in VZ?
thanks!

replies.text: I bought my Note 8 unlocked from Samsung. I'm on T-Mobile, and wifi calling works perfect. Love T-Mobile.

I want the unlocked versions SO BAD but I want all the features available on the network and unlocked versions just don't offer them. Also I can get my phone unlocked for $25 online plus I don't network jump (been with T-Mobile over 3 years).
I noted what you will/could miss with the unlocked models in my above post to Vanco333's post.
Yes, the unlocked version should work on all networks. Just pop in the sim and it will automatically set up with the new service.

Downsides of buying unlocked version and using it on T-Mobile's Network could be losing these features -
1. No RCS/Advanced Messaging
2. No 4x4 MIMO
3. No 256 QAM Technology
4. No 600Mhz Band 71 LTE Frequency ***Samsung Galaxy S9/S9+ are the first phones on T-Mobile to use the Band 71 frequency. 
Since the unlocked model would be used on multiple carriers then it probably won't have this band since that's only unique to T-Mobile. 
That's why unlocked models of any phone you buy tend to only have primary bands that all carriers in that country/region use and not carrier specific bands. 
You will definitely lose features on Verizon, they always keep a lot of their network features locked to their carrier software.

thread.text: You won't get Verizon VVM. There may be other missing feature you may or may not care about.

I had the unlocked S8+ on Verizon. I had no problem with the phone and using it. My only issue was no wifi calling. I travel out of the country 2-3 times a year and that was my biggest drawback. This seems to only be the case with Verizon.

replies.text: IIRC AT&T, Sprint, and Verizon's WiFi calling doesn't work on unlocked phones. It only works for T-Mobile on unlocked phones.

thread.text: No VVM at all, as in, when I get a VM there will be no notification icon on the top? Is Google Voice or You Mail good substitutes? I just wantvto be able to click play to get my voicemails. No need for voice to text, etc.

replies.text: You mail is great and personally what I use. Been using it for years no issues.

You'll still get a voicemail notification it's just you'll have to sit and listen to the recording of the number of who called and time stamp then the message.

title: My S9+ First Impressions coming from an S8+

thread.text:
I basically upgraded to get the 2x optical zoom on the camera, but a lot more came with it!  I think the extra 2GB of RAM makes the overall feel of the phone a good bit smoother. I'm running the 8.0 beta on my S8+, so the UI overall should be pretty similar.
I don't know if it is because it is new, but it is fast. I restored 90% of my files via the Samsung Smart Switch app. I did NOT restore via google restore. I bought a new SD card with more space and faster, but the Smart Switch didn't seem to have the ability to move the stuff from the SD card on the old phone to the SD card on the new one. It just put it in internal memory, so I ran out of space and basically did a phone reset to just start over again.
The Intelligent unlock feature works better than just the iris or just the face unlock. I haven't even turned on the finger print reader yet. Just seems like that thing has to take battery power while waiting for my finger to touch it.
SECURE FOLDER
Didn't know you could backup your secure folder files to Samsung, so I did so I could restore the files I have in there back to my new phone. Worked like a champ!
BIXBY and HOME SCREEN
Popping over to Bixby news feed is WAY faster. The S9 has the ability to view the home screen in landscape mode if you enable it in the Display settings. This also extends to Bixby news feed...it now shows up in landscape if you like.
MESSAGING APP
The messaging app changed slightly. Now it is blue instead of orange, and some of the original settings like background images are gone from the app. This doesn't bother me. I think you can still affect the background in it via a theme. The new messaging app has the ability to click an icon in the bottom right corner to record a voice message to send via text. Pretty cool when you are in a pinch.The dropdown menu that appears when you click the 3 dots in the upper right hand corner while in a text conversation is nicer. It shows the 4 most recent photos received from that contact plus most of the other stuff that used to be there. My S8 has Create Slideshow, but the new phone doesn't. Not sure what the slideshow is...never used it before. Being able to send animated GIFs easily in the new messaging app is nice. The messaging app now shows 2 lines of a message instead of just 1, so fewer messages are seen. Maybe this is a setting somewhere, but I can't find it.
AR EMOJIS
AR Emojis just don't matter right now. They aren't as creepy as everyone keeps saying. They just aren't that useful.
CAMERA APP
Love the new camera app. It is much more similar to the iPhone app where you can just swipe back and forth between the camera modes. Way easier than swiping to a screen to pick a style. Live Focus creates a great portrait style photo with changeable background blur. It holds onto the original wider screen version because the portrait shot is actually a zoomed up image.
CAMERA
Having 2x optical is pretty darn nice. Low light photos are pretty amazing. I took a picture of a black desk in low light with both. Examples are below. The interesting thing is the S8+ photo size for the photo was 3.31MB while the S9+ photo was 8.18MB. They are the same resolution and DPI. Guess there is just more data in there. There is no comparison. The S9+ took a smooth photo while the S8+ took a grainy photo.
S8+ Photo: 
S9+ Photo:
I'll post more if I find more differences that matter.
Edit 7:12pm
I totally forgot about the speakers!!! They blow away my S8+. The sound for music as well as podcasts and audio books is amazing. It is loud enough that I don't feel compelled to hook up a bluetooth speaker just so I can hear my book while I'm doing dishes at night. Having sound come at you without cupping a speaker is so nice. I know this has been out on other phones for awhile, but it is so nice to have the all the features I've been wanting in the phone I love. 
I'm in bed with Samsung for their Health App and the tracking via my S3 Frontier and Gear Fit2. They have on wrist detection that pairs whichever one with my phone automatically and blends all the stats into one app... but that isn't anything new here, just one reason why I'm in on Samsung.
Edit 7:39
Here are a couple more photos in low light. The room had little direct light, and it is getting late here in Atlanta, so no real sun light.
S8+
S9+

replies.text:
Regarding the two photos of the cabinet: besides the obvious difference in white balance, the one taken with the S9 has some motion blur and the one taken with the S8 has more detail, which is probably to be expected. It appears (at least in lower light) that the S9is using more aggressive noise reduction. 
Regarding the dog photos, the same comments. Besides the obvious difference in white balance, the photo taken with the S8 shows better detail. Looks almost like the focus missed with the S9.

title: Samsung Galaxy S9 better than OP5t ? Price per performance!

thread.text: Well many people tend to compare the price per performance, not everyone has a thousand dollar in spare to just buy a phone but everyone does demand a nice phone from the manufacturers, the one plus 5t took the media attention by storm, claiming to he faster than the iPhone x and leaving behind the s8 so Samsung has its new flagship in the shelves, is it rational to upgrade from a one plus 5t to s9 as a performance seeker or s9 is just a phone with few advanced features !

replies.text: The price is not that far apart. $719.99 vs. $499.00 So for $221 more you get a phone that has a newer better processor, water resistance,wireless charging,better camera,better display,expandable storage and the option for a lot more accessories.

If you're looking for best performance iPhone X or pixel 2. Sammy has ALL the features but a little laggy. Op5t just running vanilla Android w a little customization and a 1080p to help w speed and cost. If you like the op5t and want a better phone go pixel 2 xl trust me. The lag on the Samsung will get to you eventually.

thread.text: No one can answer that for you that's for you to figure out. It all depends what you want out of a device and what your willing to pay for. If the package suits you get it. If not get what works for you and your budget.

Define better. Will the OP5T probably beat the S9 in absolute speed. Probably. But you don't buy a Samsung for pure performance. Samsung phones are well loved because they do EVERYTHING good. They have good sound, good performance, good camera, etc. They may not be the best at anything but they are very good at everything. There is practically no compromise apart from longer update wait times. Sure if you get the OPT5T you have the fastest phone. You also lose wireless charging, water and dust resistance, get a mediocre camera etc.
If you're looking for absolute performance, look elsewhere. But is the OP5T the better phone? I don't think so. It's like asking if a Lancer Evo is better than a BMW 320. Sure the Lancer Evo is faster, but the 320 is more comfortable, better build, more safety features, and other things that overall make it better.

i've owned a oneplus 3 and it is one of the best phones i've ever owned. close to stock android made performance fly and dash charging is probably the best version of quick charging out right now. 
that being said, i would NOT spend my own money to buy another oneplus product in the foreseeable future. for as nice as the product is, the company behind it is a nightmare to deal with. the experience of sending it back in for repair gave me enough of a dull taste. long story short, it took forever and the interaction with the company made me feel as if they. were being shady. i walked away from the process knowing it was not a company i wanted to have repeated dealings with. 
so for an extra $221 that the above poster mentioned, I'm also gaining a peace of mind that my investment is backed by an established brand. 
just my 2 cents.

Up here IIRC the difference is about $350 more for the S9+. 
Said it many times if I wasn't addicted I would only buy OnePlus. 
I get the display is amazing but for $350 I can live with 1080P. Camera, Performance? Seriously, I can't tell the difference. 
I love that OnePlus is also DUAL SIM and of course the Oxygen Software is not really better but cleaner that I don't have to RELY on a third party launcher like Nova Prime.

replies.text: Saying you can't tell the difference in the camera's I don't undersatnd. But I can't tell the difference in speed. So I would rather have ip68,wireless charging, Samsung Pay and a more reputable company. Too many headaches with OnePlus customer service

thread.text:
I would think you need to define performance. Performance can mean your battery life, app launching, Gaming, photo processing/rendering etc. Yet don't upgrade to an S9/S9+ just for performance. It most likely is faster in most areas since it is a newer gen Snapdragon. However the Exynos chip phones might be even more efficient and quicker... But really why. Do fractions of a second really matter? Or do you need 50 apps open as opposed to 40?
In my opinion in everday tasks (opening email, messages, app launching etc.) the OP 5T like stated above in a couple places is a top hitter as it has OS optimization (if you want to call it that) and it has a bunch more RAM to kinda aid that. 
In Gaming (I do none...so), I would think Sammy and OP might go head to head here. I think they have in the past. Yet you are comparing two different SoC chips in this case 845 to 835.

Having owned both at same time before ( S7 / OP3 , S8 / OP5 ) you definitely get what you pay for.
Is the 5T worth £500? Probably. Is it worth paying more to get the S9 ? Definitely.
The OP6 will be inbound with the latest internals and will no doubt beast the benchmarks.
I think it is telling that most people who have a S8/9/Note 8 can afford an OP5T but don't choose them long term.

thread.text: Set up as a new phone.

Try Wakelock Detector (see Wakelock detector with non-rooted phone if the phone isn't rooted.) If something is waking the phone all night, that can do it. Also a weak mobile signal (not in neil's case - his phone is in flight mode) drains more battery. And Play can be updating a lot of apps that have gotten updates since they were put on the phone (again, probably not in neil's case).
But most phones show "bad battery life" the first few charge cycles - it's the nature of lithium batteries.

It's a Samsung phone. I had The ill-fated Note 7, S7 Edge, and the S8+. The standby time was bad on all 3. Tried with and without AOD, all different kinds of settings, everything I could think of. One thing I figured out was that Samsung phones get better than average battery life during use, but standby has never been their strong suit.

I can't seem to get android file transfer or double twist to work since I don't know how to enable mass storage. Help would be appreciated

USB Mass Storage is an outdated USB connection protocol, which would unmount a device's "internal SD" (back when Internal Storage was partitioned into a small App Installation area and a larger Internal SD that acted like an actual SD card). This hasn't been possible on more modern Android devices for a while now. What exactly are you trying to do? Do you mean MTP?
was trying to use double twist or android file transfer. both programs can't even see the phone
When you connect via USB, swipe down the notification panel and tap the USB icon -- make sure MTP (or File Transfer) is selected.
MTP is not working with older versions of Windows and/or Windows Media Player

title: New to Samsung with S9+ with questions.

thread.text:
Hello, I've switched from an iPhone 7 to the Samsung Galaxy S9+ and I'm missing some iPhone features I'm wondering if are on the S9+ that I haven't discovered yet. 
Can you control the music from the lock screen? Can you change the font color of the status bar?

Hi there! Changing OSs can be challenging, but we're here to help! Most of the time, except for iMessage, anything you could do with your iPhone you will be able to do on Android (and then some!). 
Music control on the lockscreen is possible (and from the Always On Display, too!). Just play anything and the music 'widget' will appear on the lockscreen (for AOD it's enabled by default, but you can disable it). 
As for the font color on the notification bar, it's not as simple. The S9 does have a plethora of themes to choose from that will modify the font color on many elements and even the color of the icons in the quick toggle buttons and navigation bar, but color for the notification bar (where you see the time, battery, and notification icons at the top) cannot be changed (you can change the font, though). However, some apps do allow for that element to be themed, so you can change the color, but most will require root access (the equivalent of jailbreaking on an iPhone). The only app that didn't need root on a Samsung phone (Substratum) no longer works in Android Oreo, so until (and if) they patch that up, only root apps would work.

title: Battery Life seems a consistent ding so far in reviews.

thread.text:
Unexpected. I figured that even though a brighter display, the 30% more efficient chipset would offset this some. Using external speakers that drive more watts also will drain more. If using them of course.

Then again, unless a resource heavy app or game, the main battery drain is the display and radios. The 30% 845 efficiency doesn't mean a lot otherwise.

replies.text: Isn't that the basis of a Samsung phone?

Electricity doesn't work that way. Using powered speakers uses nothing from the phone. Using plain, non-powered speakers don't "drain" - an 8 ohm speaker drains the same whether it's a little earpiece in the phone that can handle only 1mW or a bookshelf speaker that can handle 100 Watts. It's only the impedance of the speaker that determines power drain - the lower the impedance, the more drain - and a powered speaker has almost infinite impedance, so almost no current drain at all.

title: Android system webview and and game launcher are disabled and i cant enable them?

thread.text: I noticed in the disabled apps that android system webview and game launcher are disabled and it wont let me enable them if i wanted to? Is yours the same way guys?

I can't speak for the game launcher because I don't own a Samsung, but the System Webview app is a change related to Android itself. Starting with Nougat, chrome does double duty of handling System Webview functions. You can only enable it one of two ways.
The first way is to disable Chrome, then you can enable it. This has the obvious drawback of no longer having Chrome if that's your browser of choice. On the other hand, I did once have a problem with the Amazon app related to system Webview even though it was disabled. I disabled Chrome, enabled System Webview, updated system Webview on Google Play (yeah, it had an update waiting), then enabled Chrome again which automatically disabled System Webview. That fixed my Amazon problem.
The other way to enable it is via a setting in the developer options that allows both. I tried this once and it froze my phone, so I reverted that change. This may or may not be available in your phone, and YMMV if it is.
Game launcher has to be enabled. Settings-advanced features-Games

I tried different kind of chargers that I had lying around but none would charge the phone. It would just say it's charging but the percentage would not go up.
Left it to the shop for repairs. Decided to open a chat with Samsung rep. Unfortunately they where not that interested. They just said "Sorry" basically and would not take any info regarding the situation.
It was a pre-order phone here in Finland. Just hoping that the battery-fiasco from few years back is not occuring again in a different from.
Anyone else had problems?
Do you have any Samsung Support centres near you?I found them great here in Australia.. Try a wireless charging pad to rule out the type C usb socket...

Actually, the wireless charging was one I did not test. Did not actually thought about it! 
It's on it's way to repairs on Monday so let's see what they find. Yeah I talked Samsung support but as I said before, they just did not want to have any info about it, nor did they ask any specific questions. Oh well, could have been just a bad rep.
I'll definitely tell more when it's in the shops. Still a bummer that I flagship phone dies in 24 hours and it did not even leave the house
I'd seriously consider returning it if they won't exchange it. You can always buy a new one...

The Note 5 was a larger GS6, the Note 7 brought the Iris scanner, and the Note 8 brought 6GB of RAM and the dual camera set up. But no new Soc, no new camera sensor, smaller battery. While in the the Note 3 and Note 4 time they would include a new SoC, a new camera sensor, new video recording options, more ram, although Samsung did try to improve their display with every new phone they release.

title: Move to S9 - Use Smart Switch, Google Restore or do it manually?

thread.text:
I know this has been asked many times before, but I'm looking to do this right the first time. In the past I've always done it manually, as follows:
1. Setup device and connect to Google account
2. Visit Playstore and manually install all apps I need (good time for spring cleaning).
3. Backup my messages/Phone log using SMS Backup and restore to new device. Also backup Nova launcher profile and restore to new device
4. Connect both devices to PC and manually drag/drop photos, videos, etc. on the device memory to new device.
5. Move SD card with most of my stuff
6. Spend an hour or so setting up phone details - security, preferences, etc...
7. Setup all apps (monotony that can take a couple hours or more)
8. All my contacts and calendar are in Exchange. I use Nine, so I connect my exchange account to Nine and all contacts and calendar items reappear.
What do I gain by using Smart switch or Google Restore? I've been worried about transferring "problems" from one device to the next so I've historically done it manually.
Thoughts?
Smart Switch took me a good hour but I was able to get absolutely everything onto my new phone

replies.text: I believe you still need to manually setup your apps, app customizations/login state, etc. Correct?
Yes, just take a screen shot of the old device to set up the new one

thread.text: I had always used SS in the past for its easy of swapping things over until I had some problems with several S7e's that someone finally suggested may have been some bad code of some sort that I was moving from phone to phone with the smart switch. I did a reset and manually redid everything and the problem was fixed. I'd like to think SS doesn't move and of the 'muck' over to the new phone, but I'm a little gun shy after my previous experience.
How do I do this. It seem not matter which way I slide it just disappears
You should be able to open the app by tapping the notification. Swiping it away will only dismiss the notification, not open it.

title: Does the Stock SMS/Messages app still have a 1200kb limit?

thread.text:
Hey guys!

I always get a weird limit on the stock SMS app... it lets me send actual video with sound or pictures but not Gif's... it always says 1200kb limit
So I usually have to switch to Textra just to send out the gif and then return to the stock sms app which is stupid but it works
Does anyone know if the S9 still has this limitation? I know it might me carrier specific sometimes but my phone is unlocked so that doesn't really make sense to me
Thanks

replies.text: GIFs work now with the stock message app. Even the stock keyboard has them now.

MMS will always have a low limit. 
RCS will need to be in place (for all parties). 
Or just use Allo.

thread.text: It's not a phone limit, it's a carrier limit. The Android Messages app sends them differently, so it may get around T-Mobile's limit. (If they're stored on the carrier's server [which MMS is], the carrier gets to set the limit. With RCS [the next messaging protocol, which Android Messages uses], it's direct sender-to-receiver.)

replies.text: I don't use Android messages tho, I'm guessing it's the same with textra?

thread.text: I'm used to phablets/big screens so the S8+ is actually thinner than what I'm used to. It's a great phone, though. I have had no issues with it.

YES, it is too big in my opinion. I'm 6'1" with proportionate hands. I've owned huge phones like the Lumia 1500 and currently own a Note8. Just because you can do most tasks with one hand on a big phone doesn't mean it's the most ideal or comfortable experience.
Keep in mind: It's not just about the width or height of the phone, how thick the device is factors-in as well. You should be looking at the overall volume of the phone to decide if it's the right size for you, not just individual height and width measurements.
The S8+ is not the most accurate measure of how the S9+ will feel. The S9+ will feel larger in the hand than the S8+, and is about as much smaller than the Note8 as it is larger than the S8+. 
The increase in thickness to 8.5mm puts it just about on par with the Note8. 
Likewise, the S9 will feel appreciably bigger in the hand than the S8, commensurate with an increase in both width and thickness. 
My Note8 had freezing problems, so for the past several months I've been using a Nokia 8. It made me realize how much I missed phones that thin and generally comfortable to hold and use with one hand. 
I found the S8 to feel a bit small and the Nokia 8 just about perfect. The S9 will be closer in volume to the Nokia 8 than to the S8.
For these reasons, I'm going with the S9. I took the liberty of calculating the overall volume of all the phones mentioned in this post to give you an idea of how large they'll feel with one-handed use. Here's how they rank (in cubic millimeters):
1. Note8 - 104533
2. S9 Plus - 99176.13
3. S8 Plus - 94829.13
4. Nokia 8 - 88207.845
5. S9 - 86249.415
6. S8 - 81120.72
7. iPhone 6 - 63843.63
I, personally, would find the S8 Plus's volume to be on the max end of acceptable for one-handed use. If the S9 Plus was the exact same size as the S8 Plus, I might have gone with that. But my experience with the Note8 tells me the S9's volume is much closer to that ideal in-hand look and feel.
Whatever you decide, hopefully the measurements in this post help.
*EDIT: Added the iPhone 6's volume for the OP. One more thing to note, You're already getting a 5.8-inch display with the regular S9... we used to need huge phones for that display size. That's no longer the case with bezel-less displays. You're already getting a huge increase in display size over the iPhone 6 with the regular S9.

replies.text: I could care less about the increase from 4GB of RAM to 6GB of RAM, but what exactly am I going to miss with not having the dual camera?

title: Verizon Pixel XL2 or S9 Plus

thread.text: Going today would love some thoughts and opinions

replies.text: Both? In reality S9+_ is cheaper and overall a better value compared to Pixel 2 XL (I currently use Pixel 2 XL).
Better display,equal camera,expandable storage,headphone jack, ip 68 > ip67 wireless charging, Samsung Pay S9+ everyday

thread.text: I'd pick Pixel 2 XL over the S9 + 6 out of 7 days per week. But you're in the S9 forum, so most people are about to say S9+.

replies.text: Better camera at dual lens zoom, otherwise still weaker than pixel 2 xl in most of the ways that matter most for 99% of the photos people take
plus likely better speakers and wireless charging, headphone jack, and FM radio.

thread.text:
The Pixel camera is the one all others are being compared to - and its HDR+ mode still beats the S9+. (As a Samsung owner for years, I went with the Pixel.) You also get updates almost the day they're released by Google (sometimes on that day) - Samsung is notorious for late updates, or waiting a few months to combine a few fixes into one update. (I got my Pixel in early February, turned it on and it updated.)
About the only problem with the XL is the screen burn-in, but they've already addressed that. (I wouldn't go with the Verizon variant, though, if you ever hope to toot the phone or install TWRP or another ROM or kernel - Verizon locked the phone down. The Google model is the same phone, but it's not only open, Google has a couple of web pages, one for the entire ROM, one for the updates. Google has no problem with your flashing the phone, Verizon does. (And it takes less than a week to get it from Google. Time payments are about the same. No interest if you make all the payments on time. The only difference is waiting a few days - and having an unlocked phone.)
Where is s9 plus cheaper?

replies.text: Probably talking about the 128gb version. It's more expensive than the S9+.

thread.text: S9 - the pixel has an outdated processor

replies.text: lol haha

thread.text: still haven't made up my mind

replies.text: Which things are most appealing to you about each?
Pixel has quicker updates. And the s9 would have faster chip and more ram. Pricing on pixel is better as Verizon has 300 off with 275 for my trade in where as s9 is 350 with trade in. Tough choice
The faster chip and more ram thing I get, but I would argue that based on the S8 and Note 8 performance that we've seen, the Pixel 2 is probably still going to hold its own in real world performance.

"faster processor" in real-world use is going to be barely noticeable. The changes in processor speeds these days are so minimal when you look at real-world performance that you'd be hard-pressed to realize the difference. The other argument that COULD have been made in previous years is that the next-gen platform will receive support for an extra year of OS updates, but Google has negated that by bumping OS-level updates from 2 years to 3 years on the Pixel 2 line, while a Samsung is lucky to see 2. Chip-level performance improvements can be offset somewhat by optimizations in the base OS code.
More RAM? Only on the S9+, which has 6 GB. The Pixel 2 has 4 GB across the board, matching the S9...
I don't go by benchmarks, those aren't real-world use. Also, they're useless for comparing different platforms (Apple vs. Android for example, though I know that's not really the discussion here) as the app can be optimized for each. There was even an article on the front-page about the SD845 and why comparing the numbers doesn't really matter... https://www.androidcentral.com/qualc...845-benchmarks

thread.text:
I had the same debate, but for me I had to prioritize the screen quality over timely and small incremental software updates. The camera is going to be excellent and as good as the Pixel 2. Also, it helped me a great deal by going into a Verizon store and actually holding both devices in hand. Albeit, I held a S8, but it's pretty much the same feel in hand as the S9. Holding both devices sold me on the quality of the S9. I also prefer having a manual camera mode, headphone jack and expandable storage. 
In most situations, it's not about which phone is better or faster. It's about which phone will work better for you. What do you prioritize and what things are important to you. Only you can make that choice in the end. I'm currently using the G6 and by size comparison, the PXL2 is quite a bit taller so I can't imagine using it and it fitting into my front pants pocket comfortably. 
The only thing of concern to me with the S9 is the curved screen. Which is why I'll be buying a glass screen protector. The first time I will be using a screen protector with a phone since the days of plastic screens.

I'm running the Pixel camera on my Note 8 and it's giving me results that are comparable to what I had from the actual Pixel XL 2. I switched back and forth but ultimately settled on the Note because as wonderful as the timely monthly updates are, they break basic and important functionality in a subset of Pixels every 2nd month or so.

replies.text: Can you tell me more about running the pixel cam on your note 8?

thread.text: I love people saying the camera on the s9 is better or as good as the pixel 2 because of a DxO mark score. Anyone whos actually used the pixel 2 xl like myself and have seen these s9 samples and reviews know the s9 still doesn't come close. What makes the pixel 2 xl camera what it is, is its post processing. The portrait mode alone is the best in the business and in itself puts the camera above the rest. Its all point and shoot and requires no manipulation to get the best shots. You don't understand unless you have used one. The video as well is far superior thanks to its image stabilization. The s9 and s8 have a jello type stabilization which warps the image when you move and doesn't look natural unlike the pixel 2 xl which looks almost as if your are using a gimbal. Night and day.

Until Samsung proves one of its devices can go more than 3-4 months without needing a factory reset due to lag and jank, there is no question for me. Now, give me an Android One S9+ and I may be sold.
You can side load Google camera, just search for it, and you shall find 👍

I waited for the S7 over the S6, as the S7 had fixed all of the S6's faults, and the S9 appears the same over the S8. Stronger construction, thicker glass, stereo speakers, and better camera. I never buy the first model of anything and it's always served me well. Minor upgrades over the S8, but all worthwhile if you plan to keep a phone for 2 years. To me, the pixel 2 is an ugly phone, with a much worse screen (compared to Samsung). The difference in the cameras is miniscule for the typical phone user, which people are stressing far too much about

replies.text: Not entirely true. The thing that makes the Pixel cameras so great is that they consistently take great pictures even if you are not a great photographer who knows how to use all the manual modes. Most of the things that the new S9+ (not even the "plain" S9) can do require manual intervention. If you're a person who can make use of that, then it's a different discussion. But for the person who just wants GOOD pictures ALL THE TIME, without thinking about it, the Pixel is still on top from looking at the pictures.

thread.text: I'm so camera-centric for phones, that I think I would not give up my Pixel 2 XL for the S9+. But the Pixel XL is wider too. My wife has the S8+ and it is much easier to hold.

replies.text: Wait, you lost me on this one. Do you mean you'd choose the S9+ over the Pixel 2 XL because of camera? Because the Pixel 2 XL is still a stronger camera in every category that matters except for the ability to use the second lens for zoom. The Pixel 2 XL is stronger in Exposure & Contrast, Color, AutoFocus and Texture, as well as photos requiring a flash. The S9 is stronger at zoom. They're fairly close in video, although the Pixel 2 XL is winning there on everything except color, which the S9+ won on. Based on that, if you're camera centric, shouldn't you pass on the S9+ if you already have the P2XL?

Every catergory that matters? Noise doesn't matter at all? Well maybe it doesn't if most people don't notice it. But I notice it in Pixel pictures side by side with the S9.
I really don't care about DXO ratings but I have to give them credit. The S9 beat the Pixel in the noise category but 20 points, and you can see the difference in the side by side pictures too. The lack of noise in the S9 just makes the pictures look slightly more higher quality than the Pixel. 
It looks more natural while the Pixels pictures look over sharpened and really grainy. I never noticed it until I seen the S9 photos. 
The Pixel takes outstanding photos but they look slightly unnatural. Not to mention the S9 just has a lot better dynamic image IMO.
I understand the S9 camera isn't perfect and it has it flaws as well but the S9 takes the cleaner/better photo....almost every time.
If you haven't seen it already, I think it'd be cool to share your thoughts in this thread: https://forums.androidcentral.com/sa...-new-post.html

Sorry for my ignorance, as it's not something that I've really looked into. I'd love someone to give me a little heads up, the reason why it's a big deal?

replies.text:
An important point about updates that's been made a few times over the years: Samsung isn't selling you the Galaxy S7 with a grand vision of how awesome it's going to be when it gets updated to Oreo two years later. They're selling it to you in the hopes that you love what they did with the software as it was when you opened the box. 
Well there are three kinds of updates: 1) Major OS updates, like going from Nougat to Oreo 2) Incremental OS updates like going from 7.0 to 7.1 and 3) Security updates. Samsung does 1 and 3, just slowly though on 3 they are still better than most OEM's out there. On type 2 they typically ignore those entirely. 1 and 3 are definitely the most important, with I think most of us in the forums leaning towards 3 as more important than 1. 
Type 1 updates are generally bringing new features - however, with Samsung, these can sometimes be features they already had, just with a different implementation that serves only Samsung devices, while the new updates typically does it in a way to get it to all kinds of devices. An example is mutli-window. With the Samsung version, it was kinda jenky and only worked on certain apps, but they had it two years before the rest of Android got it - but now that Android has it, it actually works better and for more apps. As an example of this, Oreo was released last summer and many 2017 Samsung phones still do not have it. 
Type 2 updates are generally bringing polish to the major update and lately, for the last couple of years, there has only been one of these updates and it usually follows the Type 1 by only a few months. Call it a finishing update. 8.1 was released 3 months ago and so far Samsung has put it on zero devices, including the S9. 
Type 3 updates are monthly security updates, which Google provides the code to the OEM for about a month prior to their release schedule, and then the OEM pushes the update out. That's the one that people tend to get grumpy about. As an example of the issue here, some Samsung devices are on the February update right now, some are on December. March was released yesterday and is already available to all Pixel devices (this year's and last) as well as the last generation of Nexus devices from 2015. So best case scenario, right now, all Samsung phones are at least one month behind. 
The bigger question is... should any of this matter at all, if users don't care? Most users don't - if they did, Samsung would change their priorities. But updates are not selling phones in any sort of significant volume. For some users this is a dealbreaker, for others it's the last thing on their mind. Similar to how not having an SD card slot is a dealbreaker for some users, while others don't care in any way whatsoever. Just treat it like another feature IMO, it's either important to you or it isn't.

thread.text: I don't think any phone right now will beat what Google has done with its software. If you want a fairer match, you would have to either load up the Google camera port on the S9 or shoot both in RAW to judge from there. In just about every other situation including selfies, the Pixel 2 won't be beat. The processing is just that good. So don't judge it on Samsung's processing VS Google's processing. I think the key area that the Pixels excel in is exposure preservation. You will almost never get an overexposed shot on a Pixel phone. With the Google port on my V20 I'm seeing the same results vs the stock camera app. In manual mode I would have to compensate by shooting underexposed to preserve highlight areas and then bring the shadows up on post. The Pixel does this automatically in night and day shots. Now in lowlight video the S9 duo should outperform the Pixel since f/1.5 really just lets in a ton of light and Google can't perform their processing magic as much during video. Also audio capture has always been a weak point of the Pixel phones if you take that into consideration.

Hard to believe that the S9 isn't even in people's hands and already they're willing to say it's not a good device. I think we are living in a day when we expect absolute perfection yesterday in tomorrow's tech. I personally can't wait to use my S9 that is coming tomorrow. It's a huge upgrade for me from the LG G6.

replies.text: I have them and I love them. They are better than the S8's I had.

I'm not in that group just pointing out the question he had about the camera comparer to the Pixel 2. Personally, I think it's a phenomenal device. Not necessarily an upgrade for last years versions but for many others it definitely is. But if the Google camera port can be used on the S9/+ I think that would ease his concerns a little. Even on my V20 the differences between HDR+ and HDR+ Enhanced mirror the type of results you will get on a Pixel phone. 
HDR+
HDR+ Enhanced
No other phone's software can match the algorithms Google's team came up with.

It's not so much expecting perfection. Just improvement enough that I can justify ditching a phone I just paid 850$ for less than 6 months ago. 
The S9 both variants will be a great upgrade for a lot of folks.

By my book ditching a phone flagship bought at near launch in less than a year is never justifiable anyway. Tech doesn't move that fast enough anymore. Heck even 2 years right now is a bit of a stretch since the S7, S6, Pixel 1, V20, OP3Tand some others still perform better than some of the top midrangers released this year.
There is no real justifiable reason right now that I can see to ditch a perfectly working flagship phone in less than a year. title: From a S8 to an S9+

thread.text:
On Friday I received the S9+.
I was concerned with the size but I have to say it is noticeable only for good. The screen size makes a great difference while the phone is not unconfortable or too big. The S8 looks like a toy next to the S9+. However the S8 seems to be brighter, maybe due to the PPI.
Overall I think it makes a lot of sense such upgrade. Key benefits:
- screen size, being wider makes it easier for me to type. Media looks much better on such bigger screen.
- battery, I reckon I will get an additional hour of SOT
- camera, I was not too impressed with the S8 one but I am with the S9+. Whether it is the best in the market I do not know but it is a huge improvement over the S8. Low light and live focus are great.
- FPS, it is extremely fast. Position is better for sure but it was not a big deal for me in the S8
- 6GB RAM and new CPU makes it a powerhouse and future proof. I want to get DEX and use this also as my PC.
- 128GB storage, great for loading more media and storing the 4k videos taken.
- Stereo speakers and Dolby Atmos are a great improvement both. It is not just being louder but big improvement on quality.
- Bixby, I had deactivated before but the live translation works very well. Overall it seems less intrusive and more fluid. I have deactivated Google Assistant now as does not provide much on top.
Let me know if you have any other things you would like to know.

title: No APK installations on the S9?!

thread.text: Today I tested the S9 and S9 plus in a few stores and there and they didn't have Google accounts preloaded. The built in browser kept kicking me off APKmirror, but I managed to download GeekBench from APK4Fun. There is no "unknown sources" setting, and attempting to install an APK just gives errors. I was really hoping to get benchmark scores. Do the consumer purchased ones have this dumb limitation? If so, then I will stay away from Samsung devices in the future. I guess my Tab S3 is the LAST Samsung device that allows freedom with APKs.
I wouldn't be surprised if they have that disabled on store demo model since they are running demo software.
Demo only software on store versions for show.
hopefully it does work on the actual phone, it would suck a lot if APKs are not supported

Unknown Sources is now showing in Oreo in Apps Setting under “...” and Special Access. And in individual app, rather than under Security. 
“P” though might. How Hardware abstraction drivers and the system through new APIs in Project Treble may.

But hey, on other phones in those same stores I have had APKs work no problem in the past. The malware threat is obvious, but I am not a person who would do such uncivilized crap. I just wanted to see what SoC it had and how well it runs. I guess this is an even worse stupidity than the fact that my mid-range MTK powered phone opens the settings app faster than an S8+ (with animation scale a set to "off" on both devices)... Samsung really needs to fix issues with software on their newer phones. I also tried bluetoothing CPU-Z to an in-store S8 and the APK wouldn't install despite the "unknown sources" being enabled. Also, I cannot enable developer settings on in-store S9 phones, but I can on on an in-store S8.

Well, trying to Geekbench a store display isn't a good idea anyway. It's not going to give you accurate results. Neither is opening settings a good barometer, especially when an S8 can play Tekken 6 but I'm not sure any MTK powered device can even load the intro to that without stuttering. The store phones will be in demo mode with several aspects locked. And comparing it to the S8 demo mode also does not make sense because they don't have the same demo mode versions. 
Just wait for the full reviews if all you want is that data. Heck Geekbench themselves publish the results. Some reviewers even video the entire Geekbench and Antutu process.

Yeah, GPU in MTK devices is far from those HI-end Exynos/SD devices. But the slow settings opening on an S8 IS something that just shows how Samsung Experience has too many colorful modifications that can in some UI elements make it feel a tad bit less responsive than a Helio P20 device with near-stock Android on it. Also, hiding/restricting APK installs is a very stupid thing and I hope that that was just with the in-store S9 phones. :-( Hopefully Android doesn't become iGoogle iDroid.

title: Transferring game saves from S7 to S9

thread.text:
Hi everyone,
I'm having some very frustrating trouble trying to migrate my game saves from my old S7 to my new S9. There are many games I've been playing for the last 2 years and have significant progress in. They don't have their own cloud backups, so (like in PC, console or even the iPhone's backup and restore) I assumed you could transfer the game files but this seems to have been utterly prevented. I've tried the following, with the reason for failure:
- Samsung cloud backup: Failed because it only installs apps and not the save data
- Helium: Fails because I can't connect to it via the PC application. The phone app suggests I switch to PTP mode, and whenever I do this in the dev option, both the S7 and the S9 revert back to MTP immediately. It will not keep that change so I cannot use this app as it just sits attempting to connect.
- Moving game data across manually: Well, I just don't think I have the access to those files via the file explorer.
- Various other transfer apps: All fail to actually transfer anything other than a list of apps to install.
It seems there is no way I can see to transfer app data other than rooting the phone (which I do not want to do, and shouldn't really have to).
Is there any way to transfer app save data, or must I reset my gaming life every time I get a new phone? It seems to be unnecessarily hard 
Many thanks in advance.

Outside of a phone case what’s your favorite accessory for your phone? I never buy accessories for phones outside of a case and thought I’d change that with My S9. So what’s your favorite or most used accessory? I got a new set of wireless headphones for Christmas so don’t need that. thread.text: Yeah, agree with others on the 'it's all about your location'. In the Corning NY (central NY) area, it is ALL about Verizon. Sure others have some 'coverage' or so they claim, but not really. Puts consumers at a competitive disadvantage.
With so many deals nowadays I would purchase an unlocked device and you can use almost any carrier without being locked into just one.

I was interested in Xfinity Mobile when I heard about it, but it currently only supports iPhones. Hard pass.
Also, this:https://www.forbes.com/sites/ryanwhi...-look-closely/

replies.text:
Two issues: First, the Forbes article is out of date and false. There are parts that are true, to get the best price you need to have Xfinity Home Internet service. As for phone pricing, Xfinity charges the normal "carrier rates," which may be overpriced compared to a sale price some retailer is offering, but is still priced normally. OTOH, they often have great deals on phones -- such as now being able to get a $250 Visa gift card, though after 4 months, if you purchase a Samsung phone, and the deal includes the S9 and S9+.
And, obviously, since Xfinity sales Samsung phones they definitely don't only support iPhones. I'll give that a half true rank, since if you want to BYOD you can currently only use an iPhone -- though several have swapped the SIM into an Android after the line was set up. Though Android BYOD is supposed to be available soon. Again, though, with this being an S9 thread, for anyone wanting to switch to XMobile, this is a great time/deal since you can get the gift card with the S9.
Last, obviously the "best carrier" for an individual is based on where they live and what plans that carrier has. However, even if you have 5 (or so) Verizon lines and pay less than $45 per line, Xfinity could still be cheaper. The difference here is that with Verizon with their current Unlimited, every line has to be Unlimited. With Xfinity, you can have just a couple of lines as unlimited, with the rest pay by the GB lines. So, while you might pay $40 on all your lines with 5 lines ($200+tax/fee) with Verizon, with Xfinity you might pay $45 for two lines, $12 for two lines (1GB each) and $24 for a third line (2GB); if my quick math is right, $138 for the five lines.
One other positive, if you currently have Xfinity Home Internet then there is no hard credit pull when you sign up. Instead, they look at you current Xfinity account for the "credit check." Basically, if you have no outstanding late balance you can buy the phones on a monthly plan (no interest). Also, if for some reason you decide to leave Xfinity mobile, they do not require you to pay off the phones immediately -- instead the phone payments are added to your Xfinity Home bill, making it easier to switch if the service isn't working for you. I should mention that the phones are locked to Xfinity Mobile when you purchase them, but their unlocking policy is basically to unlock the phones on request.
Xfinity Mobile is a great deal, if the plans work for your situation (including being or signing up to be an Xfinity Home Internet customer).

thread.text: This is the same question as "what's the best flavor of ice cream" with the exception that location matters. As is obvious from above, your mileage will vary depending upon your location. In Greater Philadelphia, AT&T has deadspots which are older than many on this forum. Verizon has best Greater Philadelphia coverage; no surprise since its headquarters is here. But as you see from above, other carriers may be stronger in other areas of the nation. Generally, from my handset testing experience for the last several years, Sprint has had the weakest coverage on average nationwide.
I travel all along the East coast and Verizon never lets me down. I've tried sprint and t mobile but they just don't cut it
Verizon or T-Mobile, depending on location. If you're a traveler, cross T-MO off.

thread.text:
I cannot say AT&T is the best as that is relative, but on a large missions trip driving to the middle of an Apache Indian reservation in AZ, only my phone worked with AT&T coverage getting 3G. All the other adults and kids sporting Verizon, T-Mobile, Sprint, and Cricket had zero signal. Nothing like sharing a single phone with dozen plus kids calling home touching base with parents because they couldn't get basic cell service. 
Like I said, not sure what "best" encompasses. But it's hard to beat AT&T coverage in the states for remote areas.

replies.text: I know people that have the exact same experience as you except Verizon was the only one that worked.

thread.text: I personally have been happy with Sprint for the last 15 years, but recently have had issues when I travel for work and this is causing me to consider leaving them this year. Ultimately what is best for you is going to be different than what is best for just about everyone else. We don't live where you live (more than likely) so your best bet is which carrier is the best in your area and go with them. Sprint was great where I lived in Texas, Sprint is pretty good where I now live in Maryland, but I now travel for work once in a while and they have been hit or miss on the places I have traveled.

If you spend any time in rural areas, Verizon is really your only option. My wife and I did the T-Mobile unlimited thing last year and had to switch back because we'd lose coverage out near my parents' house. That said, the experience was great around home where coverage was good, and the staff at the stores was very accommodating.
